Risks & Challenges
There is always risk in creative endeavors because inherently we are trying something totally new. The biggest challenge will be changing the way Buffalo perceives Halloween Entertainment. In our area, people have been accustomed to going to a haunted attraction that has the most haunted houses because you feel you get the best bang for your buck. It has been this way for as long as haunted houses have been in the area. Our job is to show Buffalo that more does not mean better. You generally wouldn’t go to the movie theatre to watch as many short films as possible. A single epic movie is more effective and gives you more to think and talk about. It’s the overall quality of the experience that matters! Additionally, our experience will take the same amount of time that it would take to go through four or five shorter ones. It will take some adjustment for the Buffalo patrons to buy into this concept, but we are confident that once people start to experience our novel haunt, the word will spread like wildfire.


(Photo by Brian Machelski)
Up to this point, all of our haunts have been on real estate that did not require a lease because it was in our backyard or on a school campus. This time we will be in a building all on our own and there will be many learning experiences along the way (i.e. building permits and safety requirements, etc.). We are working closely with the Small Business Development Center on the Buffalo State campus to ensure we cross our t’s and dot our i’s. 
Other Ways You Can Help
We are SO grateful for every possible way you can contribute to our project, even if it isn’t financially. Word of mouth is the most powerful marketing tool! Recommendations to your friends are like gold. We want to build a community around this and the only way to do that is to gather more people! Use the tools provided on this page to share with your social networks if you believe in our cause. Follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. Tell your artistic friends that we are looking for artists to showcase their work, or give us a shout if you have a creative contribution for us to consider! Tell small business owners that there may be an opportunity to have a small, seasonal venue at our location. Tell students that we are looking for help in return for experience in the professional world of entertainment. Most importantly be creative, love all that you do and share positive energy wherever you go! From all at Dark Labyrinth Entertainment: THANK YOU!

story:
A complete multimedia exhibition featuring brand new works by the artist Rikki Kasso. A mix of Photography, Sumi Ink Paintings and Video Installations premiering at Deelen Art, Rotterdam. A captivating collection of artworks created over 18 months in Byron Bay, Australia.


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


OUR STORY 

As projects often do, The Silent Sirens Exhibition has taken on a life of its own. Honestly we did not intend on needing additional funds to make the show a reality but late in the game we unfortunately realized we were greatly over budget by approximately $10,000 USD. Getting lost in the passion of production had over compensated for time and money in this effort !

The exhibition will be held in two spaces in Rotterdam, one exclusively dedicated to a video installation in the ancient underwater vaults. The filming for the piece was under the tea tree waters of Byron Bay and will create a subversive experience for the viewer. The artworks in the Deelen Art space will inhabit a range of unforgettable collection of photos, large scale sumi ink paintings, and video installations based on the magical and sensual offerings of the Silent Sirens.

We are seeking completion funds in all generosity and in any capacity to enable the show to go on!


"We are seeking a true patron of the arts; big or small, young or old with an open mind and and more importantly an open wallet ! We are offering in exchange for your support, exclusive artworks, fashion and books; some of which are only available to our supporters through this campaign."


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


THE ARTIST:



RIKKI KASSO b. 1979, New York City. Currently residing in Byron Bay, Australia, the self taught art director, photographer and multi disciplinary visual artist left his native New York City for Tokyo in 2003 on an invite from VOGUE JAPAN to host a retrospective of his works from 1999-2002 at the Rocket Gallery, Omotesando. The next 9 years were spent in Tokyo (Shibuya) immersed in the unique and ancient Japanese culture which not only influenced his art making practices but permeated it’s way through his entire being. Kasso’s artistic virtuosity is effortlessly translated through a variety of mediums and expressions from photography and film to paintings, drawings, and installations. His remarkable vision is presented through juxtaposed images of feminine sexuality, timeless landscapes and heavenly realities. The artist is remarkable in his ability to maintain eroticism in his work without ever losing delicacy or resorting to crudity, to express a gesture that suggests an entire erotic narrative, sometimes dreamlike and sometimes suggestively sadistic, but always in a language of love. www.rikkikasso.com


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


THE TEAM:





"Our team made of up four extremely passionate individuals with a keen sense for fine art and creative adventures. We are the support that helps the artist to continue the creations and deliver it to the masses. Are you ready to join our team and support by starting your Rikki Kasso art collection today?"


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


SOME OF THE ARTWORKS:

“Art also is entertainment for the voyeuristic, a peek inside the mind of the creative force, a perverse analysis of an everyday activity of creating beauty. Idolising timeless preservation where mind meets matter. So in its complete reflection, my works are of an observance of the unseen, a voyeur to my own existence.“

- Rikki Kasso



Surface Static, 2015, sumi ink on watercolour paper, 86 x 61 cm


Amazing Greys (Minori), 2015, sumi ink on watercolour paper, 86 x 61 cm


Morning Wood (Ellie), 2015, sumi ink on watercolour paper, 86 x 61 cm


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


SOME OF THE PHOTOGRAPHS:

The photographs were taken in the heart of Byron Bay, more specifically on a beach and in a Tea tree lake just behind Rikki’s studio. The meaning behind the location is particularly notable for this project . These Tea Tree lakes were ancient aboriginal spas in order to fight the inevitable influence of time .



-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


THE VIDEO INSTALLATION:

Under the naturally golden tea tree waters in Tallow Creek, a woman is reborn. Breathless and alive. This video installation produced in the mystical waters of Byron Bay and projected in to the mysterious caverns of the Rotterdam Vaults with original music by J. Hats 




-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


THE GALLERY:

Deelen Art is an approachable no nonsense gallery with the motto: Playing with reality. The gallery specializes in contemporary art with a focus on realism and has a good eye for quality, craftsmanship and tradition. Bastiaan Deelen stands for clarity and transparency, operates internationally and represents the work of its artists in all relevant markets.



 

Deelen Art
Admiraliteitskade 90B

3063 EG Rotterdam
Tel 010-2362379

Info@deelenart.nl

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------



WHAT WE ARE OFFERING 

We are offering our supporters exclusive Rikki Kasso collectables from art works to books as a show of our sincere appreciation. Some of the works on offer are exclusive to the supporters of this campaign . Oh! and also you will be inducted into the very private Rikki Mouse Club as a life time member. All contributors will be Thanked and listed as supporters through out all of the Silent Sirens media (Web, Catalog, DVD). 



..............................................................................................................................................

COMMISSION ARTWORK

Check details in Perks Section.


..............................................................................................................................................

LIMITED PHOTO PRINT EDITIONS

54 X 43.5 cm

Archival Photo Print (Matte)


..............................................................................................................................................


UNIQUE SILENT SIRENS WORK ON PAPER

21.1 X 41.6 cm

unframed



..............................................................................................................................................

"TOKYO" BOOK (SIGNED)

288 Pages

color & monochrome
Printed in Japan
ISBN978-4-434-14386-1

http://rikkikasso.com/tokyo-the-book/




..............................................................................................................................................

RIKKI KASSO FASHION EDITIONS

Mens & Womens





..............................................................................................................................................


RIKKI KASSO MINI PRINT EDITIONS

5 x 7 "

Series of 3

Signed on Back







Please contact us with any question or comment.

Thank You All for the Support!

story:
Short Summary

September 24- November 5, 2015, the second Jerusalem Biennale of Contemporary Jewish Art will host nine different shows throughout Jerusalem. We are proud to announce our exhibit "Ima Iyla'a/The Supernal Mother" was selected by an eminent jury to be shown in a venue located in central Jerusalem.
Help us realize the only exhibit at the Biennale solely exploring expressions of Motherhood: The first art exhibit of its kind in Israel.  
Our international team of four professional Jewish mother artists and curators are taking on powerful forces in the art world, insisting that the multi-dimensional  archetype of mother merits serious artistic reflection and expression.  
Our exhibition expands the conversation on motherhood in the postmodern age of Jewish contemporary art.  The works provide a range of perspectives from mothers and their children, raising complex feelings and existential questions. 

Our multi-disciplinary exhibit includes works from emerging and renown artists from a variety of Jewish and non-Jewish backgrounds including Joan Roth, Joy Rose, Maya Zack, Dovid Baruch Wolk, Alana Ruben Free, David Gerstein and architect Burak Pekoglu. 

Visitors will be invited to interact and participate with the exhibited works in an attempt to realize the collective experience of mother.  An added challenge to the visual repertoire is our determination to include the ultra-Orthodox community, as both artists and viewers, within contemporary, conceptual art.
Bezalel Academy's Orthodox program and The Jerusalem Foundation are two of our organizational sponsors; however, we still do not have enough money to cover our budget. 

What We Need & What You Get
                                                                                              Contributions are tax deductable through Connections Israel. 
The Biennale Committee promises to match $1 for every $1 you contribute upto $5,000.  

The artists and their works are important to us and our team is reaching out to you to help us cover costs.   In order to exhibit with the care and quality that is required, our team needs to raise $10,000 to cover transportation, building of special installations, printing costs, and extra promotional material.

What are we offering to generous partnerships?

Supporter: ($36 or more) will receive a limited edition photograph of Alana Ruben Free and David Gerstein's "Presence=Present" which will be unveiled at the Biennale. 

Sponsors: ($100 or more) will be listed in the brochure at the front door of the exhibit. 

Patrons: ($1000 or more) names will be listed on the museum wall of the exhibit.

Creator: ($5,000 or more) you can put your name or logo on a large banner on King George Street next to the entrance of the exhibition space for the six weeks of the Biennale, alongside the title of the exhibition. 

Contributors of $100 or more who visit the 2015 Jerusalem Biennale will receive a personal tour of the exhibit by Jewish Art Scholar and Curator, Nurit Sirkis Banks or a member of our committee.

The Impact

"Ima Iyla'a: The Art of Motherhood" brings to the contemporary art world and particularly the Jewish art scene this ancient icon, the ever-evolving energy of the shechina and images of mothers, both spiritual and mundane. 
Your sponsorship is required to make this happen with quality, inspiration and meaning.
The Biennale is recognized by the Biennale Foundation, The Jerusalem Foundation, and the Jerusalem Municipality.  The project is gathering tributes to mothers from the four corners of the world. 
"The Jerusalem Biennale is a stage for professional artists, creating today, who refer in their work, in one way or the other, to the Jewish World of Content. The Biennale will take place every two years in different locations around the city and will give an opportunity for different creative forces to manifest themselves within the framework of Contemporary Jewish Art." (http://jerusalembiennale.org)

Risks & Challenges

The Jerusalem Biennale of Jewish Art is a new initiative, preparing high level exhibits for a second time.  However, the budget is limited and extra funding is necessary in order to maintain the quality platform the artworks deserve.  We are backed by Oman, the Orthodox branch of Bezalel Academy of Art, and by the Jerusalem Biennale, but we are still short of the money we need to finalize the exhibition.  We are turning to YOU to make this essential exhibit happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this with everyone interested in the Jewish Arts, Feminism in the Arts, and bringing harmony to Jerusalem and the region.  PLEASE use the share tools to get the word out.

story:
Help us bring Cuberosity to Burning Man 2015 and beyond!

What is Cuberosity?

Cuberosity is a Burning Man 2015 art project. A giant cube resting on its corner, it will appear as if it crashed into the desert and took root. Its pipe frame carries triangular shade sails into the wind, creating a 25’ tall space for people to interact, play and experience. As darkness falls, the sails turn into a shadow theater for all to participate in.

Cuberosity, a landmark visible from a distance day and night, will attract people from across the playa. There they can interact in the 1,200 square foot shaded space with others they might not have otherwise met.

Day

As the sun rises over playa, the lower shade sails open into awnings to increase airflow and transform the structure into an inviting space. Inside, people can enjoy seating and sculptures on a canvas drop cloth floor. Aerial silks may be suspended within.

Night

Images, footage and shadows will be projected on to the shade sails, making the cube glow in the night! Inside, people can dance and play with their gigantic shadows. Imagine a storyteller with gestures multiplied by his shadow. Or a dancer whose magnified body motion can be seen across playa.

After Burn

We will not be burning Cuberosity at Burning Man. It will live on. In addition to events by DC regional groups, Cuberosity will be available for events by groups from other regions, mostly Mid-Atlantic states burns and art festivals. We aim to make Cuberosity easy to transport and assemble to facilitate its re-use.

Why You Should Trust Us To Pull This Off

The DC region has a history of creating geometrical art for Burning Man starting with the DC National Treasure obelisk in 2012, followed by the DC Pyramid Scheme in 2013 and last year’s Pyramid of Possibilities. For Burning Man 2015 we’re bringing a half cube. Mark Brailsford, the project lead, worked on both the 2013 and 2014 projects.

What We Need & What You Get

We will be spending more than $15,000 to pull this off. Using all-volunteer labor, all of the funds will be used for materials like steel, shade sails, light strips, electronics, wiring, generator and insurance, as well as transportation of everything to and from Burning Man.

The first $2,500 in contributions will be matched, dollar-for-dollar, by a small group of very generous project backers!! When you put in $25... we get $50!

Of course, you also get our undying gratitude, a nice tax deduction, and awesome Cuberosity goodies.

Budget

Steel $5,000
Shade Sails $700
Floor $500
Lumber $250
Sound $300
LEDs, Flood Lights & Projectors $1,700
Generator $700
Sub Total $7,650
Transportation $6,000
Total $15,150

How You Can Help

Please donate at the level with which you are most comfortable. We'd love to be the beneficiaries of your trust fund, but no amount is too small. When we all work together and each gives even a little bit of our time, energy and resources, we can make amazing things happen. Get involved and help us build, here in DC and on playa. Another great way to help is to spread the news on your social networks to reach out to potential supporters.

If you want to donate more than the amount listed for a particular schwag item, feel free to increase your amount. We'd be very grateful.


Thank you!

We want to bring this for YOU to experience. Your help will make that happen.

Thanks for your support. See you in Black Rock City!

Specifications:

  • At over 25 feet tall, its six-sided base is 22 feet on a side. That’s over 1,200 square feet of covered space, 13,500 cubic feet.

  • The frame is made of steel pipes.

  • The triangular shade sails cover the whole structure, sporting 12" wind slits for airflow.

  • Projectors will cast light and images on the shade sails.

  • The top three edges will be lined with animated LEDs.

story:
Vovousa Mountain Festival

Hello and welcome to our campaign page! My name is Kamilo Nollas and I'm the heart and soul of the Vovousa Mountain Festival, a condensed dose of culture injected into Mt. Pindos once a year, since 2013.

Vovousa in the morning mist. Photo by George Detsis

We started this festival as a peaceful protest against the Aöos dam that flows right through my grandparents' village and threatens to destroy a way of life that has been passed down through generations. Vovousa is a traditional logger's village, quiet and sleepy, that could certainly use some new blood but not the kind the dam proposes to bring, violating national park territory.

Up until now, the magnitude of the festival extended to a weekend gathering of regular Vovousa visitors, local folk and people from nearby villages to watch films, enjoy a brief photo show and attend a music performance. Three years down the line, things have gotten serious!


We have planned a full week of film screenings, workshops, lectures, children’s activities, music performances, photography exhibitions and more, hoping to establish the Vovousa Festival as a newfound tradition. You might think this is personal - no argument there! But don't you think it's time we all took the Greek mountains personally?

What We Need

We need your support to make a lasting impression on the region. We don't want this to just be a summer fling. We want to start a new tradition, leaving infrastructure behind, so we don't have to start each festival from scratch. Here's where your money - should you choose to part with it - will go:
  • We want to host all the artists, writers, musicians etc who will donate their skills and time to make this a bigger and better festival. We want to be able to provide room and board for them all, which we are currently unable to do. [3,500 Euros]
  • We want to repurpose defunct warehouses to host cultural events, which means paints jobs and electrical wiring, seating and weatherproofing, as we would like our photography exhibition to continue well into the Fall. [1,500 Euros]
  • We want to transport and insure the artworks of five different photography shows that have to make the trek from Athens to Vovousa (300miles), which is a lot more expensive than you might think! [1,500 Euros]  
  • We want to cover website and social media maintenance, which includes everything from developer & graphic designer salaries to mailchimp credits [1,500 Euros]
  • We want to put out "Aöos", a daily newspaper issued throughout the festival, with two additional editions during the winter months, to keep Vovousa in the limelight [1000 Euros] 

       Kamilo picking up artworks from the Benaki Museum photo archives

The Impact

We want to draw people away from the siren call of the Greek islands and get them interested in the mountains instead! We want to jumpstart tourism (the respectful kind), bring culture to an otherwise isolated location and educate people on sustainability and the environmental treasures of our national parks. We want to put a definitive stop to the Aöos dam, so our children can inherit this land unspoiled, like we did. And what better way to celebrate our cause than a small yet eclectic festival by the people who love Vovousa the most!  

             Photos by Vovousa Festival 2015 artist-in-residence Achilleas Zavallis

Risks & Challenges

Let's be honest, it's only two weeks to the festival and we've already moved ahead with almost everything we were hoping to achieve with this campaign in the best way we knew how. Capital controls imposed on Greece did not allows us to launch this effort earlier, as PayPal has been suspended for our region. So the biggest challenge we're looking at right now is not being able to make payments to our service providers and festival staffers, who dove into this in good faith.

This is our first year as a full-fledged festival (yay!) and although we have a lot of "in-kind" sponsorships, we have only managed to secure 2.000 Euros in term of financial support. The crisis has not been good to nascent cultural initiatives like our own, and although we have a track record to prove we can pull this off, support has not been forthcoming. Which is why this campaign will run well into August, hoping we can run on empty until then and pay the bills after the festival is over. We're relying on you to help us pull through.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the cash, that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Connect with us on facebook, instagram and twitter and spread the word!
  • Visit our website for regular updates
  • If you happen to be in Greece, book your passage to the festival and get a front row seat to our blood, sweat and tears!

It's totally worth it!

Meet The Team


Kamilo Nollas: Founder
A natural-born photographer and cultural instigator, he entered life in Paris but subsequently lives and works in Greece, because there's no place he'd rather be. Freelance provider of beautiful images to online and print outlets, photography instructor and Fulbright scholar, he has made the Vovousa Festival his life's work

Dimitris Drougias: Co-Founder
Civil engineer, amateur woodworker, mountain biker. Born in 1976, he's a distant cousin to Kamilo, but then again everyone in Vovousa is somehow related. He's restless and endlessly curious. He has been an avid supporter of the festival right from the start, coming up with magical solutions when everybody else was about to give up.

Despina Pavlaki: Press Officer
A multitasker by nature, she's a journalist, translator, documentary producer and several other things (including children's book writer), depending on the circumstance. She has worked at festivals in Athens, Thessaloniki and Cyprus, which only served to teach her that smaller is better. 

Iliana Alexandrou: Designer
An esthète par excellence, Iliana is behind all the Vovousa Festival's design needs. She has the ability to bring the beauty out of pretty much anything, banking on details to elevate the big picture to near-unattainable aesthetic heights. "Let the beauty of what you love be what you do" is her life motto.  

George Detsis: Photographer
Born in 1965, Detsis is a photographer and nature-lover, determined to pass down his gifts to his young son. With a higlhy successful career in newspapers and magazines, he is the owner of a stone-built house in south Pindos, where he likes to spend his holidays with his family sans electricity.

Kathrin Haltiner: Cultural Manager
As an architect she is familiar with a broad range of tasks from hands-on construction to abstract organizational matters. An interest in culture and art completes her practical side. Thus photography - as an art and as a means to communicate - and Greece - as the cultural root of Europe are topics close to her heart and she is happy to help the festival wherever she can!

Zafeiris Karampasis: Web Production
Born in downtown Athens in 1981, he studied sociology and acquired an MA in “Virtual communities: Socio-psychological perspectives & technical applications”. He worked with both business and non-profit organisations in a number of new-media projects as well as in developing, designing and editing websites & social networks and in integrated online-presence strategy planning.

Vovousa Mountain Festival

Hello and welcome to our campaign page! My name is Kamilo Nollas and 
I'm the heart and soul of the Vovousa Mountain Festival, a condensed 
dose of culture injected into Mt. Pindos once a year, since 2013.

Vovousa in the morning mist. Photo by George Detsis
We started this festival as a peaceful protest against the Aöos dam that flows right through my grandparents' village and threatens to destroy a way of life that has been passed down through generations. Vovousa is a traditional logger's village, quiet and sleepy, that could certainly use some new blood but not the kind the dam proposes to bring, violating national park territory.

Up until now, the magnitude of the festival extended to a weekend gathering of regular Vovousa visitors, local folk and people from nearby villages to watch films, enjoy a brief photo show and attend a music performance. Three years down the line, things have gotten serious!





We have planned a full week of film screenings, workshops, lectures, children’s activities, music performances, photography exhibitions and more, hoping to establish the Vovousa Festival as a newfound tradition. You might think this is personal - no argument there! But don't you think it's time we all took the Greek mountains personally?What We Need


We need your support to make a lasting impression on the region. We don't want this to just be a summer fling. story:
My 7-year old daughter, Kylie, has struggled through more emotional turmoil than any child her age should ever have to experience and yet her spirit is unbroken. She has found her own outlets and talents and I have had the pleasure of watching her confidence grow she takes her own journey down the path self-discovery. In gymnastics, she has advanced two levels beyond her age group and she continues to put forth effort and hard work into learning new skills. She says “Mommy, my dream is to be in the Olympics someday.” Kylie is also very much enchanted by science and nature and she can’t get enough of the outdoors. Whether it’s fishing, swimming, camping or just walking through the woods, when she is surrounded by the beauty of nature it is plain to see that she is in her happy place.  Unfortunately, with the rising cost of summer camp and after-school care, I don’t think we can afford the cost of gymnastics or camp on my salary this summer.

Sometimes life may take you down a rough path, but the universe will always provide you with enough tools to survive. Even if those tools are hidden deep within. The resources are there if you look hard enough and are willing to go to any length. My burden of privilege is the eternal care for another life that I created. Sometimes my economic insecurities get the best of me and I am unable to provide the life I wish I could for my 7-year-old daughter. I was blessed with an artistic talent that has served no real purpose in my life aside from the ability to express myself on paper. I realized that my abilities may serve a greater purpose than for my own enjoyment. I hope to fund my daughter’s talent in gymnastics and her many other interests, with my talent in the arts and with your support.

story:
HI

I’m Tanja, and I’m fundraising to attend LARA, which is the London Atelier of Representational Art.  The course starts on September 28th 2015!

LARA?

At LARA, they teach art as draughtsmanship. They focus on the fundamental technical elements of drawing and painting, in the classical Italian atelier set-up.

  

Drawings : Luca Indraccolo | Instructor at LARA

  • "Influenced by the Atelier Method of instruction, the unique emphasis of this course is the practice of working directly from the life model. A continuous pose of no less than a week and up to a month under unvarying light, gives optimum time to observe the figure and understand how to “see”. Working with tutors 6 hours a day and using the “sight- size” method we aim to teach essential concepts of proportion, line, gesture, form and light to best master expression of the human form." ~ LARA

At LARA I will learn the tools I need to express the visions I have, to translate into paintings what I feel about this world and to capture what I see when I look at the beauty every single person carries within them.

WHO AM I

I am a painter living and working in North London. I moved from Germany to the UK in my early 20ies to attend university and whilst there discovered a much deeper way to express myself, through painting.

I knew I had to pursue a career in art when I met master painter Rosa Branson MBE in late 2009. I didn’t know anything about drawing or oil painting then, but fortunately Rosa took me on as a student.

Rosa and I (once painted and once in person) at the unveiling of Rosa's painting for Moorfields Eye Hospital.

Over time, Rosa developed enough faith in me as a painter, not only to mentor me, but also provide me with accommodation and a studio in her home. She will continue to support me in this way throughout the whole of my studies at LARA.

Rosa’s encouragement, inspiration and tough advice have been essential to my journey; so much so that I became a full time painter in 2012. I have never looked back!

WHAT HAPPENED SINCE THEN?

The last three years have been great! I’ve learnt so much about painting and life as an artist. I got to copy at London’s National Gallery and the Kunstpalast in Düsseldorf.

Left at the National Gallery in London and right at the Kunstpalast in Düsseldorf.

I’ve taken part in exhibitions:

  • 2016 The Worlington Movement Spring Exhibition, Bury St Edmunds
    2015 Hesketh Hubbard Art Society Annual Exhibition, Mall Galleries, London
    2015 The Worlington Movement Spring Exhibition, Bury St Edmunds
    2014 The British Red Cross Charity Exhibition and Auction, Japanese Embassy, London W1
    2014 The Worlington Movement Autumn Exhibition, Sable d'Or Muswell Hill, London
    2014 The Reading Art Exhibition, St Joseph's College, Reading
    2014 Hesketh Hubbard Art Society Annual Exhibition, Mall Galleries, London
    2014 The Worlington Movement Spring Exhibition, The Old Fire Station Gallery, Henley-on-Thames
    2013 The Reading Art Exhibition, St Joseph's College, Reading

I have learned to frame my own paintings, connected with people from all over the world and made terrific new friends. I remember jumping with joy the first time I sold a painting to a complete stranger, and the excitement of receiving my first Mosaic Mural commission.

Mosaic Mural on behalf of Paritt Leng Construction and Management Ltd at Bethwin Adventure Playground, Camberwell, London

Now; for the next step: Classical Training

Going back to basics in order to reach the next level in my career; to feel whole as a professional painter. LARA's three year, full-time course is exactly what I need to fill my technical gaps and move towards my full potential. That is why I am here; raising £15000 for the first year's tuition and materials, taxes and fees.

WHY SPONSOR ME?

Over the years I have had to take chances to get where I am now. Through the rough and the smooth, I have always been blessed with amazing people and the right opportunities to keep on track. I am hoping that as you get to know me throughout this fundraising campaign, you will want to be one of these amazing people who take a chance on me.

For just £10 you get access to exclusive content, sharing with me, my journey to LARA and my time there. I want YOU to become part of my progress of growth; to see me develop as an artist.

For higher donations you will receive artwork, most of it originals – who knows it may be worth a lot one day!

So stay tuned for more videos about perks, about me and LARA, interviews with my mentor and previous clients, and answers to any questions you may have.

Welcome to my journey. Thank you for joining me!


P.S. Where does the money go?

The main part of the money raised will cover LARA's tuition fees of £9000/ year, with the rest going towards materials, Indiegogo fees and taxes to HMRC, which will make up another big chunk. Any money left will be put towards year two tuition fees at LARA to get further crowdfunding of to a running start!


P.S.S. What about perks?

Most of the perks are quite straight forward. There are online perks, prints, original sketches, drawings and paintings as well as murals.

Online perks will be activated as soon as the donation is received.

A5 Prints will be send out throughout August and September 2015. The six print options (three black and white/ three watercolour) will be made public throughout July when the best ones are chosen. A5 is an approximate size. Actual measurements will be as close to A5 as possible but will depend on what best suits the motive.

A5 Original sketches will be completed as soon as possible on an ongoing basis and will be send out as soon as they are done. Please note: original art takes time! If all 200 sketches are claimed they will be completed within 6 (six) month. Please message me if you are buying this perk to a specific deadline to check whether it can be fulfilled in time. A5 is an approximate size. Actual measurements will be as close to A5 as possible but will depend on what best suits the motive.

Examples of black and white/ watercolour sketches

A4 Original life drawings will be completed as soon as possible on an ongoing basis after the completion of year one at LARA and will be send out as soon as they are done. Please note: original art takes time! Please message me if you are buying this perk to a specific deadline to check whether it can be fulfilled in time.

Original oil and mosaic paintings will be completed as soon as possible on an ongoing basis and will be send out as soon as they are done. Please note: original art takes time! Especially works in oil have a long drying time with each layer taking up to ten days to set. Please message me if you are buying this perk to a specific deadline to check whether it can be fulfilled in time.

Examples of recent oil paintings; Parrot, Lilies and Rose, Three Rabbits


Examples of Mosaic paintings; Heather and Jamie's Commission, Female Portrait, Phoenix Rising III


Mosaic Murals will be scheduled for out of term time. Christmas and Easter breaks for indoor works/ summer break for indoor and outdoor works.

Bethwin Adventure Playground Mosaic Mural, 2014  - ca 60 sq m

Kidz Kabin Muswell Hill Mosaic Mural, 2015 - ca 30 sq m

story:
What is the Parallel Georgia Project?

We at the Parallel Georgia Project do what we do to promote the cultural input and output of Georgia’s millions of individuals. We seek to encourage productive conversation among all Georgia's creators. We seek to promote unrestricted access to arts resources.

Each month, from August of 2015 to July of 2016, two creators without a significant arts background are given $500 grants and are awarded exhibition space at one of our associated galleries.  
We believe that art is everywhere, and that all voices deserve to be heard and considered. We want to encourage a community, a conversation around a truly vibrant arts world.

What does your donation do?

 As a year-long project, no money is paid to the operators. This means that 100% of all monies collected go directly to gaining submissions, providing artist grants, and exhibiting the work of creatives across the state of Georgia. 

Any donation can help make an impact in an artist's life. And their art can make an impact in someone else's life. Imagine the momentum we can build!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Spread the word about our campaign to others!
  • Tell those artists in your life to submit their work!
  • If you're in Georgia, contact us about outreach and volunteer opportunities!

In the end, the Parallel Georgia Project is about community. We believe in connection. We believe in community. We believe in the arts.

Any donation can help make an impact in an artist's life. And their art can make an impact in someone else's life. Imagine the momentum we can build!

    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:  Spread the word about our campaign to others! Tell those artists in your life to submit their work!
If you're in Georgia, contact us about outreach and volunteer opportunities!   In the end, the Parallel Georgia Project is about community. We believe in connection. We believe in community. We believe in the arts.

story:
Bettie Page: Lost and Found

     In 1987, I began my search for the missing Pin-up Queen. For the next seven years I tracked down the people who knew her and eventually Bettie herself. The culmination was an extensive Page interview in "The Betty Pages Annual V.2" and there didn't seem to be anything more to tell on the subject, so I discontinued the title. Bettie's legend continued to grow and her fame reached all corners of the Earth. Even though I stopped writing about her, our relationship continued and we spoke often. Almost all of our conversations were recorded (with her permission) and I have hours of her observations about life and her new-found fame. I also stayed in touch with most of the major players in the story and continued to discover details I'd missed the first time around. Almost thirty years after I started, I'm satisfied that the research is complete and I am about to write my final book on the Queen of Curves. With the death of Harry Lear, her last husband, nothing I write can hurt Bettie and her friends: they have all passed. There are stories that I had discovered while I was publishing "The Betty Pages" that I refused to tell and stories I've learned since then that are eye-opening. Since nobody can be hurt, I'm ready to tell the full story.

     It's been some twenty years since I've written about Bettie and also twenty years of her life that has not been reported on. What happened to La Page after she came out of hiding? What was her life like? How did it change her? Who helped her or screwed her over in the end?  It's the other half of the Bettie story that you don't know.

     At least half the book is already written and I estimate that it will take another six months to complete and publish. As I am producing it for my publishing company, Pure Imagination, I am receiving no advance to complete the book. Hence, I'm asking for your help to pay the bills while I complete the project, most importantly paying for the printing. "Bettie Page: Lost and Found" will be issued in both deluxe hard and soft-covers and I'd like to issue it in full-color, but that depends on how much the Bettie fans are willing to contribute. If you would like to help me complete Bettie's story, please consider assisting its production.

     Anybody contributing at the $30 level or more will receive a copy of the soft-cover edition whether the goal is met or not and all contributors will receive a signed, limited-edition of the cover. If the goal isn't met, it may take a little longer, but the book is going to be published one way or another. If you can help get the word out I will very much appreciate it.

     The final product will contain dozens of previously unpublished photos, new interviews, and the most complete view of Bettie's life ever published. If you liked my previous work on "The Tease From Tennessee," please consider contributing to what I believe is a worthwhile project that will amuse, amaze, and delight you.

story:
Short Summary

Vogliamo aprire l'ex Convento di San Domenico. Una realtà conventuale domenicale che fu tra le piu' importanti del Sud. Divenuto sede di importanti servizi pubblici, è stato abbandonato per essere restaurato. Da oltre 20 anni è un cantiere e rischia di rimanere tale per tanti altri anni. 

What We Need & What You Get

Abbiamo bisogno di finanzianziare l'installazione di una mostra d'arte.  L'arte è un ottimo passpartout per aprire porte rimaste chiuse per troppo tempo.  I fondi raccolti servono per fare manifesti e pubblicità alla manifestazione.  Nessuno dei partecipanti ottiene viene pagato per partecipare all'operazione.

The Impact

L'ex Convento di San Domenico è un edificio troppo importante per il centro storico di Venosa per essere tenuto come un rudere nella piazza principale di Venosa. La mostra e le manifestazioni culturali che organizziamo all'interno sono la prova piu' evidente che quel luogo ha una vocazione importantissima per la città e che ha bisogno di essere restaurato e riporatto ad una piena funzionalità. Candideremol'edificio ad un progetto FAI. 

Risks & Challenges

La sfida è molto alta. Raggiungere l'obiettivo del restauroin un momento di crisi degli investimenti pubblici e privati è molto difficile. La nostra manifestazione deve stimolare una iniziativa forte per candidare un progetto importante. I rischi sono solo quelli che prossimamente le attività cittadine ritornino ad essere contaminate dal pensiero.

Other Ways You Can Help

Lo sforzo che ti chiediamo è veramente minimo. Oltre ad offrire un tuo contributo in denaro passa la voce.

story:
Keshia's H.E.A.R.T.

In 1996 Keshia Thomas was attending a protest against the Ku Klux Klan, a white male with an ‘SS tattoo’ and wearing a Confederate flag t-shirt found himself in the midst of the protesters. The man was knocked down and beaten, Keshia shielded the man and stopped the attack.

Photographs of her amazing act of bravery, refusing to meet hate with hate, have made their way around the world spreading inspiration and hope.

Keshia continues to be a voice for what is right. Her heart is to help hope, equality, acceptance, respect, and tranquility to override disparity in the United States. Regardless of what differences of skin, background, opinion, education, or economic status we have, Keshia will continue to use her voice to help right wrongs and to find and embrace balance.

What's Next for Keshia?

1) Her Journey

 On August 1, 2015, Keshia will take part in the NAACP's "America’s Journey for Justice" – a historic 860-mile march from Selma, Alabama, to Washington, D.C to lobby for change.

This journey will "mobilize activists and advance a focused national advocacy agenda that protects the right of every American to a fair criminal justice system, uncorrupted and unfettered access to the ballot box, sustainable jobs with a living wage, and equitable public education." (Source: naacp.org)The walk will end with a rally and advocacy day in Washington, D.C. 

Compelled to participate, Keshia has made a great sacrifice by taking a leave of absence from her job. This sacrifice will cost her income, insurance and stability however, Keshia sees  this all as a small sacrifice in relationship to the great injustices we all still see as American citizens in 2015. Keshia walks as a demonstration of her heart and this journey is the new beginning of her endeavor to serve as an advocate, activist, and advisor on issues affecting humanity.

2) Her H.E.A.R.T.

Educating people in relationship to handling issues surrounding racial intimidation within schools and workplaces. Racial intimidation within primary and secondary education is real, and takes place more often than people realize. When faced with a situation that requires the school staff to respond to racially fueled incidents, there is often a lack of knowledge on how to do so. Keshia plans to offer training on how to effectively handle situations between school staff and students. She will also be able to provide companies with training for those in management, on how to deal with racial intimidation between employee's.

3) Her P.O.I.N.T.

Born in Detroit, Michigan but raised in Ann Arbor, Keshia currently resides in Houston, Texas. With renewed excitement, Keshia is moving back to Detroit in order to be a part of another great renaissance for the city by launching her non-profit organization, P.O.I.N.T. (Purpose. Opportunity. Independence. New Thinking.)

P.O.I.N.T. is an initiative that brings affordable incubator space and resources to the city of Detroit. These resources will help cultivate the  ideas of people into viable small businesses and will help them from the germination phase (idea,) to the vegetation phase (implementation) and finally onto harvesting (independence). These resources are aimed at those who see their dreams as impossible - those who have been afraid to dream as a result of their circumstances. 

P.O.I.N.T. will offer them space for the business to thrive, access to resources to structure the business for success, and mentorship for guidance and growth. The purpose is to create jobs and work towards a self-sufficient economy in the city of Detroit.

What Keshia Needs

The vision is great but it can't be fulfilled without support. 

  • $2,500 for America's Journey for Justice to provide Battle Gear: Clothing, shoes, supplies, and sustaining resources for the march (i.e. food, sleeping bags, backpacking supplies, airfare to Alabama and back to Houston, and resources to maintain her housing while marching)  
  • $2500 for curriculum development to educate schools and companies on how to correctly deal with  racial intimidation through Keshia's H.E.A.R.T. 
  • $5,000 in initial seed money to start the process of launching her non-profit, Keshia's H.E.A.R.T. and the P.O.I.N.T. incubator initiative. 

What You'll Get

Your support is appreciated!  Here are gifts from Keshia's H.E.A.R.T.

  • $10: Social Media Shout-Out
  • $25: Postcard from Keshia's Journey
  • $50: Keshia's H.E.A.R.T. T-Shirt
  • $100: Autographed 2016 Keshia's H.E.A.R.T. Calendar
  • $500: Keshia's historic photo framed and autographed by both Keshia Thomas and photographer, Mark Brewer
  • $1000: Phone call from the journey (and all of the above!) 
  • $5000: Lunch or Dinner meeting with Keshia in Washington D.C. on September 17th, 2015

The Impact

Keshia's historic picture gained nationwide recognition, and from that platform,  she plans to empower and enlighten young minds, and stand up for solidarity.

  • She plans to work with those who do not know how to deal racial discrimination situations.
  • Keshia's goal is to bring a fresh voice to address the racially fueled events that have taken place, and to advocate for acceptance and unity.

Risks & Challenges

Keshia is leaving her job and taking a leaping of faith. She is stepping out to be a voice to help change the perspective of society.

  • Keshia is determined to help hope, equality, acceptance, respect, and tranquility override disparity. She entered the public eye by making a selfless decision and sacrificing her own well being to help someone else. Keshia will continue to use her life to advocate for a healthy America void of racial divide. 
  • Keshia has accepted that there are sacrifices necessary to stand up and advocate for what is right. As many have done before her, Keshia believes that these sacrifices are investments into a better future for those still feeling the unnecessary weights of racial inequality and intimidation.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Spread the word and make some noise about Keshia's Heart. Join in the effort to help those around you embrace the promise of a healthier society for us all and for future generations to come.
  • Share the Keshia's heart and mission socially!  Send via Facebook, twitter, Instagram and beyond. Together, we can be solutions to the problems!

Keshia has accepted that there are sacrifices necessary to stand up and advocate for what is right. story:
Five years ago, The Big Hammock made a rocking appearance at the Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy Greenway. Back by popular demand, The Big Hammock is going to be reinstalled at Adam's Park in Roslindale this August! This has been made possible through our collaboration with another non-profit organization, RoslindaleVillage Main Street, whose mission is to bring local businesses to strengthen the Village's economic vitality and local character. Beginning in August, every Saturday from 9:00AM to 1:30PM, The Big Hammock will accompany the Roslindale Village Main Street's most successful Farmers' Market in bringing a fun-filled weekend of festivities and some serious relaxing. This initiative at Adams Park is incredibly important to BR+A+CE's mission:  to bring good public art accessible to all. The Roslindale Village Main Street is celebrating its 30th Anniversary on August. 8th with the mayor Marty Walsh being present. With this 35' long hammock, you and all your friends are cordially invited to the Roslindale Farmers' Market this August!

We want it back, but...

WE NEED YOUR HELP!

The 2015 Big Hammock needs some extra love and care. This year we have made purchases in materials and supplies, such a pole protector bumpers and signs to keep your children extra safe from any injuries when they are having BIG fun. These costs to build this 33 feet hammock (get excited!), is costing us $3,700. The 2010 Big Hammock was only made possible because of your generosity and excitement for projects like this! Our organization relies on people like yourselves, and the capability of crowd fund raising.

To see a complete breakdown of our costs to reinstall The Big Hammock, please see the attached PDF here.

Aside from crowd funding, The Big Hammock in 2010 was a huge success because of an incredibly devoted volunteer group. Likewise, the 2015 Big Hammock is brought to you by a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization BR+A+CE: Building Research + Architecture + Community Exchange in collaboration with the Roslindale Village Main Streets and Farmer's Market.

THE VOLUNTEER TEAM...

...is comprised of designers, fabricators, students, and faculty brought together by BR+A+CE's Officers and Board of Trustees.  The Big Hammock has been led by Project Manager Ellen Woodsbie (RISD, 2016), Connie Wang (RISD, 2016), Hanhan Luo (RISD, 2015), and Shiqing Liu (Harvard, 2016) and BR+A+CE co-founders Anthony Piemarini and Hansy Better Barraza. We have been fortunate to be aided by the volunteers of the Roslindale Village Main Streets and Farmers' Market, Lucy Galvan, Maddie Siebert, Ben Sommer, Christina DiLisio, and Mark Smith.

Installation of The Big Hammock in Adam’s Park would not have been possible without these awesome volunteers:

  • Jake Schmidt (RWU)
  • Joanna Grocott (RWU)
  • Matthew Aiello (RWU)
  • Taylor (RWU)
  • Lise Bradford
  • Michele Audet
  • Cathy O’Keefe
  • Anna Litten
  • Brian Johnson
  • Sara Domingo
  • Ben Warner
  • Adam Rogoff

Many hands have helped us get to where we are; please visit our website for a complete list of volunteers and sponsors.

All donations to BR+A+CE are tax-deductible. Please contact us directly at info@br-a-ce.org if you require formal acknowledgement of a donation for tax purposes.

To get involved and follow our progress, please visit our official website and like us on Facebook!

SOCIAL MEDIA

www.br-a-ce.org

www.facebook.com/braceBOSTON

http://twitter.com/HansyBetter

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?   What We Need & What You Get Break it down for folks in more detail:  Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.  Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited! Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.    The Impact Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:  Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world. Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one). Make it real for people and build trust.    Risks & Challenges  People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.  Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles. Describe your plan for solving these challenges.    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:  Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!   And that's all there is to it.

story:
What Is Bedtime Stories?

"Don’t fret my child,

Stay calm as can be.

Don’t be afraid,

your fear attracts Boogie.

Be calm, Be calm, 1, 2, 3

If you surrender your soul,

You cannot ever flee. "

Bedtime Stories is an environmental installation that simulates what its like inside the mind of someone with an anxiety disorder, through the visual exploration of different versions of the Boogie Monster myth. It's a walk through experience, like a haunted house, that shows the world of two sister’s bedroom that has become possessed by the Boogie Monster. 

 Welcome To My Head (Inspiration and Background)

The inspiration for Bedtime Stories came from a series of weird storytelling games I created to cope with my peaking anxiety disorder my freshmen year of college. At the time, I had not been diagnosed or treated, nor did I have an idea of what I was dealing with. What I did know, though not really understood, was what I was experiencing. So, I channeled my inner child to help make sense of it all. As a young adult, I didn't know how to conquer my overwhelmed mind, but as a child I did know how to conquer the monsters in my closet and under my bed. So, perhaps I could conquer my grown monsters just the same. I assigned faces, figures, and names to the horrors that kept me locked in my room and in my head, and I made myself the heroine of my own stories.  I allowed the rooms around me to become part of this children's storytelling game, because if I made the rules, I knew how to win the game, I knew how to make it through the spaces that had previously overwhelmed and held me back. So, when I started brainstorming for my capstone, the idea of taking these experiences and allowing others to be part of them, to perhaps come to an understanding of one persons fantastical perspective of a very real problem led to the development of Bedtime Stories.

This installation is meant to be an exciting and unique experience, but also a very stylized glimpse into one persons experience with anxiety disorder. I don't, nor can I, propose a solution to fixing this growing and often ignored problem in our society, but I can share whats inside my head, in hopes of creating, at least some, insight.

Bedtime Stories will be exhibited to the public in early May. 

Budget

Who's Head Are We Entering? 

Hello, I'm Alejandra Gama, a senior Theatre student at Arizona State University. I will be receiving my BA this coming May. Throughout my college career I have had the joy of working in various disciplines on different productions. My previous work includes scenic design for It's Not That Simple (ASU Applied Project), Dog Sees God (Phoenix Center for the Arts), Bug (BTC), Finger Painting For Grown-Ups (BTC), Drowning. But Not Falling (BTC), prop mastering  for Germs and Viruses: Or the Syrian Spring (ASU Mainstage) and Brooklyn Bridge (ASU Mainstage) and costume design for Women of War (BTC) and Necrosis (BTC). I am the current Scenic Design Representative for Binary Theater Company. I've also had the pleasure to exhibit my multimedia sculpture "In Commemoration of a Little Bird: A Visual Eulogy" at Emerge 2014: The Carnival of the Future.

My career aspirations are to become an environmental installation artists, blending all my previous work in various disciplines into one experience.   

While this project is a focus on my fears, it is with great excitement that I push to bring to fruition this multimedia experience, with my wonderful and unique team.


Collaborators  

 

        Ryan Lee Kirkpatrick (Sound Artist) is a senior Theatre major at ASU. He is the Media Design Rep for Binary Theatre Company. His previous media designs include, Unkindness (BTC), Shallow Grave (ASU), Skulk (BTC) and Reefer Madness (LOT) which was Zoni nominated. His previous sound designs include Women of War (BTC) and Finger Painting (BTC). He has also recently wrote and directed his own play, Necrosis at Binary Theatre Company. He aspires to be a goth glam opera metal performer. His fears include small spaces, losing loved ones, dirty places and failure.

 Zoey Crow (Media Artist) is a sophomore at Arizona State studying film and media design. She has previously co-media designed for Skulk and media designed for Necrosis, both through Binary Theatre Company. When she is not doing homework or working on a show, she spends her time watching Netflix and hanging out with friends. Her favorite TV show is Orphan Black and her favorite movie is The Perks of Being a Wallflower. Her biggest fear is to not make anything of herself. 

Trenton Flores (Light Artist) is a third-year undergraduate student studying Theatre Design & Production with an emphasis on lighting design. His most recent design credits include Women of War (Binary Theatre Company) and Germs & Viruses (ASU Mainstage). In addition to lighting design, Trenton is currently looking to explore other creative avenues such as writing and musical composition. Trenton is interested in classic rock history, Japanese animation, and the psychology of escapism. Something Trenton is afraid of: Confined spaces (Claustrophobia). 

Marie Tucker (Production Manager) is currently a freshmen at Arizona State University pursuing a BA in theatre. This is Marie's second project that she is taking part in at ASU. Her first was the Binary Theatre Company production of Necrosis which she stage managed. Marie has also been on stage, as much as she has been off stage, three of her favorites being Into the Woods, Godspell, and Fair Exchange. Marie is not only interested in theatre, but political science as well. In the future Marie hopes to become and actress or stage manager either in New York or Los Angeles. Marie has a fear of snakes. 

Megan Burns (Costume Assistant) is a freshman theatre student at ASU. She's been designing costumes for local theatres around the valley, and has received the opportunity to work on the board of Binary Theatre Company as Costume Representative Apprentice. Costumes are her hobby and passion, and she plans on pursuing a career in that field. Megan happens to be terrified of clowns, and of rejection from herself and society.

Jackie Nguyen (Scenic painter and illustrator) is a drawing student in her senior year at ASU. Her previous work includes the exhibition and marketing of her work in the ASU Student Arts Market, drawing and painting in collaboration with multiple artists inintermedia art projects A Woman's Spiritual Luminance and Exhaling Outside the Box, as well as the completion over 400 hours of instruction and training in ASU Life Drawing studio courses. Each of these experiences combined  will contribute to her goal of being an independent illustrator. She has a fear of snakes and rats. 

Sabrina Dahlmann (Performance Instructor) is a senior double majoring in Psychology and Sociology as well as double minoring in German and Theatre. Previous credits include performing in: Women of War(Binary Theatre Company), Trenchcoat in Common (B.T.C), The Girl Who Fell through the Hole in Her Sweater (B.T.C.),  The Seven Layers of Bastian Bachman (ASU), Macbeth (Grassroots Shakespeare) andThe 39 Steps (Mesa Encore Theatre). You can see Sabrina next in the upcoming ASU MainStage production of She Kills Monsters. Sabrina is fearful of surgery and what happens after death. Sabrina is also phobic of snakes because they are too fast and have scary fangs. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate? That's perfectly fine! Please help us get word out about this project by sharing online. Any help is appreciated!

story:
Le miraculeux nivellement du plancher de Caravansérail

Situé dans un ancien cinéma de la ville de Rimouski au Bas-Saint-Laurent, le Centre d’artistes Caravansérail doit renoncer à plusieurs projets soumis par des artistes à cause d’une pente dans la salle qui nuit à la présentation des œuvres ou des projets.


L'objectif de notre projet

L’objectif de la campagne de financement participative Le miraculeux nivellement du plancher de Caravansérail est d’amasser 10 000 $*. Avec votre précieuse contribution, nous envisageons de construire des structures amovibles sur mesure dans le but de niveler une partie de la pente du plancher de la salle d’exposition pour favoriser la tenue de divers projets de sculptures et d’installations dans notre espace de diffusion. 

* Grâce au programme de Mécénat Placements Culture qui triplera le montant des dons recueillis par les organismes auprès de donateurs pour constituer des fonds de réserve.

Crédit photo : Martin Côté.


Les impacts de la pente

La construction de nos structures amovibles permettra à Caravansérail de continuer à diffuser le travail d'artistes émergents en région, et ce en plus grand nombre. Pour assurer la bonne continuation de notre mandat, de nos activités de diffusion et le rayonnement de notre organisme sur la scène nationale, Caravansérail a besoin de votre appui!


Trois options s’offrent à vous!

Catégorie TITAN :


Catégorie DIEU DE L’OLYMPE : 


Catégorie DEMI DIEU : 



Un DON* à la campagne de financement participative Le miraculeux nivellement du plancher de Caravansérail. Pour tout don émis, vous recevrez un reçu pour déduction ou crédit d’impôt provincial. Chaque dollar amassé lors de notre campagne de financement 2015-2016 sera triplé grâce au programme Mécénat Placements Culture et nous aidera à accumuler un fonds de réserve pour la construction d’une structure amovible. Donc, tous les dons, qu’ils soient petits ou très grands, sont les bienvenus! 


Un ACHAT parmi les choix suivants :

L’achat de l’un de ces produits permet au Centre d’artistes Caravansérail d’enregistrer des revenus autonomes.

  1. Publication Espaces Blancs Édition limitée;
  2. Sac de chips autographié par Jean-François Provençal, nombre limité;
  3. Paquet de macarons officiels de la campagne de financement Les travaux de Caravansérail. Cupcake, manette de jeux vidéo, sceau de la campagne de financement.
  4. Macaron de Jean-François Provençal qui mange des chips.

Le Centre d’artistes Caravansérail vous réserve des activités à saveur ludique et éclatée avec son porte-parole officiel, Jean-François Provençal, comédien et humoriste du groupe d’humour absurde Les Appendices !

La campagne Les travaux de Caravansérail, inspirée des travaux d’Hercule, place le donateur au centre de l’évènement, l’invite à participer à nos levées de fonds pour ainsi réaliser l’impensable et devenir un héros! Quatre activités de financement sont prévues au cours de 2015 et 2016.


Bref...


D'autres façons d'aider

Partagez notre projet, parlez-en à votre famille et vos amis, suivez-nous sur Facebook et Twitter !

Les activités du Centre d'artistes Caravansérail vous intéressent ? Abonnez-vous à notre infolettre ! Pour en savoir plus sur notre mandat, nos activités et l’historique du Centre d’artistes Caravansérail.

story:
Marginal Visibility 

A research and development project by Manchester based artist Rosanne Robertson making links between science and art focusing on mental health and the modern condition of anxiety resulting in the development of  newly exhibited sculpture, performance, sound art work and publication. 

This period of development is based from artist led space The Penthouse supported by Center for Chinese Contemporary Art, working with scientists at Manchester University. Dedicated research into anxiety in art via forms such as performance sculpture, assemblage and sound sculpture will be carried out at and with the support of Henry Moore Institute (Leeds). Professional development sessions are supported by hÅb. Initial works and mini publication to be launched at Sluice 2015 (London). 

Research will be published, exhibited and performed via a dynamic platform including mental health awareness projects, open studio, exhibition, performance and events to launch the project publications and sound art works. 

This campaign will: 

  • Help me fund the publication I am making as part of this project
  • Help extend the community for this project
  • Make a unique document linking mental health, recovery and contemporary art.

By helping to fund this project you will be helping to make a very unique publication combining mental health research and new practical research into making art that communicates tensions and anxieties related to mental health disorders. The book will act as an art work itself and you will be a patron of the arts whilst supporting a new and emerging artist making work as described by 'Doodlebug' in Dazed and Confused as "a provocateur who tirelessly works across all platforms, creating work by any medium necessary and who works beneath the skin". 

What is needed & What you get

Funding will enable the nuts and bolts of making the first run of the project book:

  • Photography for the publication
  • Copy editing of the publication
  • The design and production of the publication
  • The printing of the publication
By funding the book you will become part of the project, you will: 
  • Be listed as a supporter and patron in the book
  • Be invited to a small number of special performances with 20 audience members as part of the project which involves live documented experiments with sound and sculpture. 
  • Receive a one off art work from the project- ranging from small print editions to one off artworks. 
The production of this publication is a big part of this project. It will help widen the audience of the project and communicate some of the research and personal stories that can not otherwise be communicated. 
The publication helps make the project more accessible. A number of copies of the book will be reserved at cost price for unemployed people and a selection will be made free for any homeless persons who would like the book. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If financial support isn't feasible for you right now- you can support the project by helping spread the word and contributing to calls for the project via twitter #marginalvisibility 

---

Rosanne Robertson is an artist working with performance, sculpture and sound who graduated from Manchetser School of Art in 2009 with a first class honors degree in Fine Art. Rosanne has exhibited and performed across the UK and nationally including performing at Les Instants Chavires (Paris), exhibiting at Foundation 11 (Wuhan, China) and carrying out artist residencies in Switzerland and New York.

story:
Die Flotte der Freiheit schwärmt AB SOFORT aus, um Menschen aus Ost- und Südeuropa aus unwürdigsten Bedingungen zu befreien.

Alle die selbst nicht fahren können, haben die Möglichkeit über Spenden zum Kampf um den europäischen Traum beizutragen.

UPDATE: Am besten sind Sofortspenden an die Leute die runter fahren, da das Indigogo Geld erst 15 Tage nach Kampagnenende zur Verfügung steht. Wer eine Sofortüberweisung vornehmen kann/will bitte Email an uns: europeandream@posteo.net.

Die Haltung von Menschen in Käfigen ist nur ein Beispiel für den Verrat an Europa, der im Umgang mit Menschen auf der Flucht tagtäglich stattfindet.

DIe Flotte der Freiheit schwärmt aus für all diejenigen, denen es nicht selbst möglich ist nach Budapest zu fahren und dort ihre europäische Bürgerpflicht zu erfüllen.

Hunderte Autos brechen in diesen Momenten Richtung Osteuropa auf.

Das Herz Europas liegt nicht in der Politik. Es liegt im Volk. Es ist das Volk.

Die Zustände, für die der Budapester Bahnhof exemplarisch steht, werden wir nicht länger hinnehmen. 

Die Flotte der Freiheit wächst mit jedem Euro der gespendet wird.

Alle 500€ fährt ein Auto los

In dem Moment, in dem das Minimalziel von 500€ erreicht ist, wird die erste Flotteneinheit Richtung Osteuropa aufbrechen. Besetzt mit 2 Fahrern und 3-5 freien Sitzen für Anhalter, sowie ausgestattet mit genügend Verpflegung für Hin- und Rückfahrt.
Sobald 1000€ erreicht sind, rollt das 2 Auto los usw.

Für jedes Auto werden 50€ Rechtshilfe einberechnet, da nicht auszuschließen ist, dass die Verteidigung der Menschenwürde auch weiterhin von bürokratischen Kleingeistern belästigt wird, die noch nicht verstanden haben was Europa ist.

"Es ist eine wunderbare Erfahrung, dass Mauern eingerissen werden können"

- Angela Merkel -


Die Grenzen innerhalb Europas sind nicht zu aktzeptieren.
Die Missachtung der Menschenwürde wird von uns allen beendet werden.

"Jede Person hat das Recht auf Freiheit und Sicherheit."
- Art. 5 der Europäischen Menschenrechtskonvention -

Handeln ist alternativlos.

Die Politik versagt.

Die Verteidigung unserer Werte übernehmen wir nun selbst.

Das europäische Volk erwacht aus seiner Unmündigkeit und emanzipiert sich von der Bürokratie. 


Es geht los.
story_txt:
Die Flotte der Freiheit schwärmt AB SOFORT aus, um Menschen aus Ost-
 und Südeuropa aus unwürdigsten Bedingungen zu befreien.

Alle die selbst nicht fahren können, haben die Möglichkeit über Spenden zum Kampf um den europäischen Traum beizutragen.
UPDATE: Am besten sind Sofortspenden an die Leute die runter fahren, da das Indigogo Geld erst 15 Tage nach Kampagnenende zur Verfügung steht. Wer eine Sofortüberweisung vornehmen kann/will bitte Email an uns: europeandream@posteo.net.
Die Haltung von Menschen in Käfigen ist nur ein Beispiel für den Verrat an Europa, der im Umgang mit Menschen auf der Flucht tagtäglich stattfindet.
DIe Flotte der Freiheit schwärmt aus für all diejenigen, denen es nicht selbst möglich ist nach Budapest zu fahren und dort ihre europäische Bürgerpflicht zu erfüllen. 
Hunderte Autos brechen in diesen Momenten Richtung Osteuropa auf. 
Das Herz Europas liegt nicht in der Politik. Es liegt im Volk. Es ist das Volk. 
Die Zustände, für die der Budapester Bahnhof exemplarisch steht, werden wir nicht länger hinnehmen. 
Die Flotte der Freiheit wächst mit jedem Euro der gespendet wird.
  Alle 500€ fährt ein Auto los
In dem Moment, in dem das Minimalziel von 500€ erreicht ist, wird die erste Flotteneinheit Richtung Osteuropa aufbrechen. Besetzt mit 2 Fahrern und 3-5 freien Sitzen für Anhalter, sowie ausgestattet mit genügend Verpflegung für Hin- und Rückfahrt. Sobald 1000€ erreicht sind, rollt das 2 Auto los usw.Für jedes Auto werden 50€ Rechtshilfe einberechnet, da nicht auszuschließen ist, dass die Verteidigung der Menschenwürde auch weiterhin von bürokratischen Kleingeistern belästigt wird, die noch nicht verstanden haben was Europa ist.
  "Es ist eine wunderbare Erfahrung, dass Mauern eingerissen werden können" 

- Angela Merkel -
Die Grenzen innerhalb Europas sind nicht zu aktzeptieren.Die Missachtung der Menschenwürde wird von uns allen beendet werden. "Jede Person hat das Recht auf Freiheit und Sicherheit."- Art. 5 der Europäischen Menschenrechtskonvention - 
  Handeln ist alternativlos. 

Die Politik versagt. 

Die Verteidigung unserer Werte übernehmen wir nun selbst. 

Das europäische Volk erwacht aus seiner Unmündigkeit und emanzipiert sich von der Bürokratie.  


Es geht los.

story:
Mega Man Rage-stick 2.0

Greetings, and thank you for checking out my funding page!

My name is Kyle, and 5 years ago I created a Mega Man rage-stick (totem, sign, etc.). I've brought him to many outdoor music festivals and events, mostly Summer Camp in Chillicothe, IL. I live in Peoria, IL, so I go to that festival every year. Also Umphrey's McGee is my favorite band, and since they're there every year too that works out well.

It's been a joy taking him to shows. I've been able to meet countless people that love the same music and festivals I do, as well as those that share my love for Mega Man.

What I'm looking for:

I'm asking for help funding my next generation Mega Man. The original has been to many shows and fought many battles with the rain, wind, dust, and mud. He's a little worse for wear. I think it's time to retire his jersey, and build his replacement.

I've set my goal at $1,000. I realize that may seem like a lot for a rage-stick, but this will be much more than the average signs you've seen at festivals. I have big plans for this upgraded model that include the following:

  • High quality vinyl prints
  • Reinforced internal skeleton for strength
  • High powered LED strips with color changing capabilities and remote control
  • Integrated water gun to cool off the crowds during the hot mid-day shows
  • Detachable sling-shot style glow-stick launcher to accent the drops and breakdowns from the artists on stage
  • Integrated Bluetooth speakers for Mega Man music and sound effects
  • Detachable pole for ease of travel and access to indoor events


Mega Impact

Creating this new model will help bring joy and novelty to my fellow festival-goers. People love to see him rocking out at all the best shows, and they love to be reminded of their favorite 8-bit classic games. My favorite thing is watching people's faces light up when they ask to rage him for a song or two. I'm happy to share the joy that is Mega Man. He's there to uplift everyone's festival experience.

Risks & Challenges

I have some really big ideas for the new model, and I have the basic plans laid out. However with any creative project that has functional implications, there will be some unforeseen issues. Some of my biggest concerns are as follows:

  • Building a strong yet lightweight skeleton
  • Developing a concealed method of mounting replacement batteries for LED strips
  • Building a simple and functional sling-shot for the glow stick launcher


Other Ways You Can Help

I would really appreciate a donation, but if you would rather not I would also very much appreciate you sharing this funding page on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc.

Thank you for reading! I'm looking forward to raging with you!
