story:
Since its beginning in 2010, the Graffiti of War Project has been working tirelessly documenting rarely seen art created by veterans, local nationals, and even civilians specifically originating in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Kuwait.  Through our outreach efforts, thousands of images have poured in from all corners of the world submitted via our website and social-media pages. As the interest exploded, project founder, Jaeson Doc Parsons, a former combat medic, traveled to Iraq and Kuwait to document as much as possible before they were destroyed following the withdrawal of Coalition Forces.

As unrest in Iraq has continued following ISIS' violent take over and the civil war in Syria, more conflict art has appeared across the region. As these works of art are temporary by their very nature, we must act quickly to capture this unique and rarely seen genre of art before they are lost forever. With this in mind, we have started to prepare for another expedition to this volatile region. The money raised will have a dual purpose. Part of these funds will send two team members to Iraq and Syria for several weeks in order to document this artwork before the elements erase their very existence, adding to what is already the largest collection of conflict art in the world. This collection will be presented to the world via a series of photobooks to showcase these stunning works of art, many of which no longer exist outside of our collection. 
Another portion will help us finalize our book and prepare for its groundbreaking book tour. This tour will feature the artwork we captured presented on unconventional canvas and in astonishing sizes as many of these murals were in excess of 40 feet by 20 feet. A truly extraordinary event providing a unique perspective on conflicts which have affected the entire world since September 11th, 2001.

The ultimate aim for this project is to raise awareness for those men and women, soldier and civilian that suffer the silent wounds of war, PTSD & TBI. Our goal is to promote and advance alternative therapies for these unseen wounds such as arts therapy. We believe this book and the tour will be a bridge over the ever-widening gap between military members and civilians providing healing for both the artist and the spectator. Proceeds from every book and piece of art sold will go directly to partnering organizations to help them fund alternative therapies for PTSD.

A Fox News Interview about Graffiti of War
 

For those interested in knowing more about the Graffiti of War Project, our mission, the 2017 expedition and book tour contact info@graffitiofwar.com.  More information can also be found on our website at www.WallsofWar.com as well as www.GraffitiofWar.com.  During this IndieGoGo Campaign we will be releasing more details concerning the upcoming expedition and any new developments concerning the National Book Tour to include dates and locations.

 

 

The Impact

As this war continues, our nation has become silently divided, the widening divide between soldier and civilian grows with each year. It has become more and more difficult to understand the life and trials of a deployed soldier and their family. Although most Americans support our brave men and women, they don’t grasp the magnitude of what effect this conflict and subsequent deployments have on the families as well as the mind and soul of the soldier. 
In documenting and showcasing these images created by soldiers, marines, and airmen as well as local nationals in Iraq and Afghanistan, our aim is to give a unique glimpse into the minds of those who endured these conflicts. To provide America an inside look at what has gone almost entirely unseen to the vast majority of the public. Many of these images are raw and created in the moment on unconventional canvases in a very unconventional war. Exhibiting this artwork will help civilians get a better understanding of how it is to be separated from family, to lose one of your own in a blink of an eye, to get a feel, a taste of what 15 months fighting a very unpopular war is like. To bring understanding to Americans not familiar with the emotions of war.
 

Risks & Challenges

The bold ambitions and objectives of this Project, like anything worthwhile, will not be accomplished without a price, and the burden of our short-term and long-term goals are too much for our team to shoulder alone if we are to ensure the resounding success of what we have set out to achieve.  

These needs are not ours, but the needs of those brave warriors, this Nation’s citizen soldiers, who were affected by the conflicts of our world.  They willingly answered with service and sacrifice to a Nation that called, and now we united citizens of that Nation must answer the call to help these wounded warfighters in return.  This project is committed to that mission, and we are searching for individuals and organizations throughout the U.S. and the world that are ready to stand with us in that commitment . . . Semper Fidelis.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially that's ok! There are various ways to assist in The Graffiti of War Project’s mission such as supporting our efforts to spread the word on social media to anyone and everyone. You can simply use IndieGoGo's Share Tools and forward our campaign to those who might want to contribute.
Please feel free to visit our website, www.WallsofWar.com or www.GraffitiofWar.com for additional information on this exciting project and exhibit. All of our contact information is listed there and we would love to hear from you!

story:
"Small pleasures must correct great tragedies,
Therefore of gardens in the midst of war
I boldly tell.."
 The Garden- V. Sackville-West


Conflicting Realities: New Art from Syria 


Essentials

·  We are fundraising for an exhibition of young Syrian artists telling the stories of Syria through their work

·  The exhibition will take place in London in 2016

·  Medium: Painting, Sculpture, Photography, Digital Work, Film, Video and Installation


About Me

My name is Rami Yazje. I’m a civil engineer by training and have worked in business consulting in the UAE and the UK. 

I was working in London when the economic downturn hit and I was laid off. I moved back to Syria at the end of 2009 to launch my painting career (I paint large abstracts in the style of abstract expressionism). As the country disintegrated, I made the difficult choice to leave in early 2015. I relocated to Istanbul, Turkey, where I am now based.

I met many interesting artists during my time in Syria but due to the obvious difficulties faced by everyone in the country at the moment, there is little infrastructure for exhibition or to maintain a vibrant contemporary art scene. Knowing that I would be relocating to London in 2016, I began to think about how I could showcase the work of young Syrian artists who, through their work, are telling the untold stories of life and the strange reality of Syria today.

Art has always been a passion of mine and the overall plan is to open a gallery in London, exhibiting work and representing artists. New Art from Syria will be the first exhibition I will stage in London and will mark the beginning of a whole new series of exhibitions and projects both in the UK and worldwide!

Link to my LinkedIn Professional Profile

https://tr.linkedin.com/pub/rami-yazje/2/961/252

Link to my Saatchi Artist Profile

http://www.saatchiart.com/rami


Why London?

·  Vibrant art scene and market

·  Stable political and economic climate

·  Freedom of expression...

·  More exposure. Bigger chance of taking the exhibition on the road afterwards!


What the Exhibition is about?

The exhibition will tell stories from Syria through the work of emerging contemporary Syrian artists. A ‘Picture’ will emerge of a country ravaged by war, apocalyptic scenes of death and destruction, corrupt politics, evil ideologies and human suffering on an astronomical scale. The artists will have complete freedom within the exhibition and its context within London to express themselves. Artistic insights challenge the way we see stories reported by the media and also record this key moment in time. We don't know what will happen for Syria but it's so important to witness, express, create and record!

The Campaign

I have been researching and planning this exhibition project since late 2014. I have been contacting artists and receiving many positive responses. There are so many talented young and emerging artists based in and out of Syria that are interested in participating and showing their work. A project like this, however, needs funds to make it happen and I soon realised the funds I currently have do not match the scope and scale of the exhibition I would like to do. If I'm going to do it, i want to do it right and do justice to the artists involved!

 Money donated to this campaign will be used most conscientiously to serve one aspiration: to create an exhibition that will change perspectives, create opportunity, change lives and, hopefully for the future, go some way towards easing the suffering of Syrians everywhere..

So this is how the money will be spent

·  $25,000: Hire of large, visible and well-known exhibition space in London/Dedicated exhibition staff and technicians/Fixtures and fittings

·  $15,000: Shipping of artworks from all over the world

·  $15,000: Marketing/Website/Publication/Promotional Material

·  $10,000: Funding of independent projects/new commissions and collatoral programme as part of the Exhibition

·  $11,000: Perks (We have some great perks - check them out!)

·  $4,000: Indiegogo fee


I am 100% committed to holding the exhibition. If the campaign does not reach its funding target, I will have to downsize across the board. I will hire a smaller space and spend less on shipping, marketing and funding of independent projects, etc... but I sincerely hope that I won’t have to do that and that’s why I need your help.. So please give as much as you can, spread the word and ask your friends and family to contribute. This is a great opportunity for you to become part of something grand, a life-changing event!

People need to hear what Syrian artists have to say about one of the biggest human tragedies of our times! Understanding is a first step towards healing!

We are including the names of all of our benefactors in a special section of the exhibition. Also, campaign contributors can win unique and original artwork or a collection of artworks by a single artist. Furthermore, for top contributors, you will be flown to London to attend a private viewing event of the exhibition.

Thank You!

story:
Changing Landscape

ABOUT THE PROJECT

Changing Landscape is a photographic reasearch supported by Townhouse Gallery in Cairo.

In my training years and during my work experience I had the chance to collaborate with many artists and architects who look at landscapes and architecture as a metaphor of the time in wich we are living .
Using the border line of Red Sea as a metaphor for constant change I want to photograph the landscape and people along its banks from Suez to Elba National Park. Although it has never been my intention to take documentary pictures, the sociological context of this project is very important and ever-present.
By retracing this rout I would like to document the shifting morphologies , the modern infrastructures resulting from urbanization and the juxtaposition of deserting landscape.
The understanding that photography, taking architecture as its main subject, has the ability to communicate wider truths about society is fundamental to the project presented.
Representing the antrophized territory has to mean representing the built environment, but beside the documentation the project is a research about contrast between tradition \roots and innovation, (for example the growth of modern architecture facing the presence of berber camps that persist at the borders of the desert) .

ABOUT ME

My name is Barbara Rossi.
I grew up on a camper van and ever since childood I started using photography as a tool to map the world around me and record places. Nowadays my investigation is based on observation and analysis of relationship betweem man,territory and time. I use photography to understand situation, to understand the particular shifting from modernity and post modernity reflected in the environment I live in. Materials for my research are the signs left by man on the landscape and over time, such as architecture, or objects which express man’s relationship with the time in which he lives, in the civilization of the past and that of today. I read architecture and urban enviroments as metaphors for the society that inhabits it.

Here is my portfolio
http://barbara-rossi.tumblr.com/



TOWNHOUSE GALLERY RESIDANCY PROGRAM
Townhouse Gallery will host in Cairo me for a 2 months residancy program.
During this time we will organize some Open Talk and will invite local\non local artists and architects to discuss about landscape transformation.

http://www.thetownhousegallery.com/
If you are artist, curator or architect who works in this field you could be invited to lead a Talk in Cairo.

CONTRIBUTE
In order to realize the photographic project I need to travel trough Egypt and I need to find a reliable person who can drive me. This requires money :)

If I don't reach the entire goal I will use your money to print some good pictures of mine and I' ll sand it to you (you can choose from my portfolio).

If you can't contribute just make some noise about my campaign or give me some good contact in Egypt!



Thank you!
\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\


ITALIANO


Changing Landscape è una ricerca fotografica supportata da Townhouse Gallery, una galleria che offre residenze per artisti al Cairo.

Changing Landscape è una ricerca fotografica sullo sviluppo delle città contemporanee nel Governatorato del Mar Rosso. A seguito di un periodo di ricerca presso Townhouse Gallery al Cairo, il progetto prenderà corpo “on the road” lungo la strada costiera che connette Suez al confine Sudanese, con l'obbiettivo di documentare il cambiamento e le trasformazioni in atto lungo la costa del Mar
Rosso.
L'Egitto ha stanziato 150 miliardi di dollari per investimenti
immobiliari, molti dei quali si svilupperanno lungo costa desertica.
Utilizzando la linea di confine tra deserto e acqua come metafora degli opposti, intendo concentrarmi sullo sviluppo dei nuovi centri urbani nel deserto,sull'innovazione architettonica contrapposta alla tradizione locale e sui cambiamenti morfologici in atto in un paesaggio consolidato.
Durante la residenza organizzerò delle Open Talk presso Townhouse invitando artisti e architetti per riflettere sul concetto di paesaggio; le Talk saranno aperte al pubblico e sarà un modo per coinvolgere la comunità e le istituzioni locali.
La documentazione del paesaggio, sia esso naturale o antropico, è
innanzitutto un fatto etico ancor prima che cognitivo; è la necessità di essere testimoni del presente, prendersi cura del proprio tempo.
Changing Landscape intende testimoniare un “ciclo di vita” di un paesaggio che si trasforma ogni giorno; un momento di transizione per luoghi destinati a profonde trasformazioni, scenari che già non esistono più.

SU DI ME
Il mio nome è Barbara Rossi.
Sono cresciuta su un camper e fin da ragazzina la fotografia è stata un modo per mappare il mondo intorno a me e ricordare i luoghi.
Oggi la mia ricerca è basata sull'osservazione e sull'analisi delle relazioni tra uomo, territorio e tempo.
Vedo nel mezzo fotografico uno strumento sopraffino per comprendere situazioni, per cogliere il passaggio tra modernità e postmodernità riflesso nell'ambiente in cui vivo.
Materiali della mia ricerca sono i segni lasciato dall'uomo sul paesaggio e sul tempo, come l'architettura o le grandi opere stradali (oggetti che esprimono la sua relazione con il tempo in cui vive).

Potete vivistare il mio portfolio al link seguente
http://barbara-rossi.tumblr.com/

e uno dei miei ultimi porgetti al link seguente
http://www.domusweb.it/it/portfolio/2015/04/07/barbara_rossi_ss9_inventario_della_via_emilia.html


Contribuendo al progetto potrete avere una stampa fotografica del progetto, oppure qualcosa che voi sceglierete dal mio portfolio.

Se non potete contribuire economicamente, fate girare il progetto, condividetelo e parlatene ai vostri amici!


Grazie!
story_txt:
Changing Landscape
ABOUT THE PROJECTChanging Landscape is a photographic reasearch supported by Townhouse Gallery in Cairo.In my training years and during my work experience I had the chance to collaborate with many artists and architects who look at landscapes and architecture as a metaphor of the time in wich we are living .Using the border line of Red Sea as a metaphor for constant change I want to photograph the landscape and people along its banks from Suez to Elba National Park. Although it has never been my intention to take documentary pictures, the sociological context of this project is very important and ever-present.By retracing this rout I would like to document the shifting morphologies , the modern infrastructures resulting from urbanization and the juxtaposition of deserting landscape.The understanding that photography, taking architecture as its main subject, has the ability to communicate wider truths about society is fundamental to the project presented.Representing the antrophized territory has to mean representing the built environment, but beside the documentation the project is a research about contrast between tradition \roots and innovation, (for example the growth of modern architecture facing the presence of berber camps that persist at the borders of the desert) .ABOUT MEMy name is Barbara Rossi.I grew up on a camper van and ever since childood I started using photography as a tool to map the world around me and record places. Nowadays my investigation is based on observation and analysis of relationship betweem man,territory and time. I use photography to understand situation, to understand the particular shifting from modernity and post modernity reflected in the environment I live in. Materials for my research are the signs left by man on the landscape and over time, such as architecture, or objects which express man’s relationship with the time in which he lives, in the civilization of the past and that of today. I read architecture and urban enviroments as metaphors for the society that inhabits it. Here is my portfolio http://barbara-rossi.tumblr.com/TOWNHOUSE GALLERY RESIDANCY PROGRAM Townhouse Gallery will host in Cairo me for a 2 months residancy program.During this time we will organize some Open Talk and will invite local\non local artists and architects to discuss about landscape transformation.http://www.thetownhousegallery.com/If you are artist, curator or architect who works in this field you could be invited to lead a Talk in Cairo. CONTRIBUTEIn order to realize the photographic project I need to travel trough Egypt and I need to find a reliable person who can drive me. This requires money :)If I don't reach the entire goal I will use your money to print some good pictures of mine and I' ll sand it to you (you can choose from my portfolio).If you can't contribute just make some noise about my campaign or give me some good contact in Egypt! Thank you!
\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\ITALIANOChanging Landscape è una ricerca fotografica supportata da Townhouse Gallery, una galleria che offre residenze per artisti al Cairo.Changing Landscape è una ricerca fotografica sullo sviluppo delle città contemporanee nel Governatorato del Mar Rosso. A seguito di un periodo di ricerca presso Townhouse Gallery al Cairo, il progetto prenderà corpo “on the road” lungo la strada costiera che connette Suez al confine Sudanese, con l'obbiettivo di documentare il cambiamento e le trasformazioni in atto lungo la costa del MarRosso.L'Egitto ha stanziato 150 miliardi di dollari per investimentiimmobiliari, molti dei quali si svilupperanno lungo costa desertica.Utilizzando la linea di confine tra deserto e acqua come metafora degli opposti, intendo concentrarmi sullo sviluppo dei nuovi centri urbani nel deserto,sull'innovazione architettonica contrapposta alla tradizione locale e sui cambiamenti morfologici in atto in un paesaggio consolidato.Durante la residenza organizzerò delle Open Talk presso Townhouse invitando artisti e architetti per riflettere sul concetto di paesaggio; le Talk saranno aperte al pubblico e sarà un modo per coinvolgere la comunità e le istituzioni locali.La documentazione del paesaggio, sia esso naturale o antropico, èinnanzitutto un fatto etico ancor prima che cognitivo; è la necessità di essere testimoni del presente, prendersi cura del proprio tempo.Changing Landscape intende testimoniare un “ciclo di vita” di un paesaggio che si trasforma ogni giorno; un momento di transizione per luoghi destinati a profonde trasformazioni, scenari che già non esistono più.SU DI MEIl mio nome è Barbara Rossi.Sono cresciuta su un camper e fin da ragazzina la fotografia è stata un modo per mappare il mondo intorno a me e ricordare i luoghi.Oggi la mia ricerca è basata sull'osservazione e sull'analisi delle relazioni tra uomo, territorio e tempo.Vedo nel mezzo fotografico uno strumento sopraffino per comprendere situazioni, per cogliere il passaggio tra modernità e postmodernità riflesso nell'ambiente in cui vivo.Materiali della mia ricerca sono i segni lasciato dall'uomo sul paesaggio e sul tempo, come l'architettura o le grandi opere stradali (oggetti che esprimono la sua relazione con il tempo in cui vive).Potete vivistare il mio portfolio al link seguente http://barbara-rossi.tumblr.com/e uno dei miei ultimi porgetti al link seguentehttp://www.domusweb.it/it/portfolio/2015/04/07/barbara_rossi_ss9_inventario_della_via_emilia.htmlContribuendo al progetto potrete avere una stampa fotografica del progetto, oppure qualcosa che voi sceglierete dal mio portfolio.Se non potete contribuire economicamente, fate girare il progetto, condividetelo e parlatene ai vostri amici! Grazie!

story:
Initial pre-orders have closed but Part 2 is now open with the same perks available... follow the link below

https://igg.me/at/hamfisted2/x/11443077

Ham Fisted, Half Cocked Book & Exhibition

What is a retrospective and what life does an artwork have once exhibited and it's purpose served?

I'm raising funds for a 'retrospective' book and exhibition of my recent work, to be shown initially at Back Lane West in Redruth. Its not going to be a formal, bland, retrospective but more an exploration int
o the life of artwork after it has been shown and what becomes of it. The exhibition will feature new and old work formed into a new installation exploring the idea of what happens to old work. 

The book itself will document the exhibition itself as well as featuring archive images of a selection of my previous exhibitions and artworks - giving them a way to live-on. 

The exhibition will be the first part, set for April this year with the book to follow soon after.

For an idea of the work to be included see some of my portfolio of previous work here

What I Need & What You Get

I need about £500 to fund the first run of books and the help towards the additional materials and costs needed for the exhibition. The books and other perks are being pre-sold through this platform as a way of raising the money needed. 

The Book

A cloth bound, professionally produced artist 'retrospective' book to go alongside the exhibition (although published later) featuring quality colour images and text.

  • Grey, perfect bound, hardback, cloth cover (similar to image but this may very)
  • Minimum of 40 pages but final number may vary
  • It will feature what I see as my best and most successful works over the last few years as well as new work, older pieces, unseen work and models/sketches.
  • There will also be images from the exhibition as well as accompanying texts.

The Exhibition

A tongue in cheek exploration of my artistic journey so far to feature a new sculptural installation. The installation will expand into the space evoking ideas of something between a storage system for used and new/unfinished work and a chaotic theatre set. It will both seek to celebrate and commiserate the pieces within and their varying successes whilst giving them a new life after death.
The phrases Ham Fisted and Half Cocked suggest a clumsy, or not fully committed attempt at something; perhaps my own opinions of my artistic journey thus far or perhaps a reference to the nature of retrospective shows themselves.  

The exhibition will be a temporary event based show featuring an opening night and weekend (dates tbc) with the work evolving in the space over the preceding week.

Any backing would be greatly appreciated! Thanks!
