story:
We (Em and Sade) are two best friends who, beyond all else, love books. We spent our entire childhoods in bookstores and libraries. Sade is an author, Em is a former librarian.

It has been a lifelong dream of both of ours to own a bookstore. Unfortunately, we live in a location where opening a brick and mortar store just isn’t financially viable for two people to start from scratch.

So, we thought of the next best thing; we decided to purchase an ex-bookmobile and convert it into a full time living space and bookstore, circumventing the need for pricey overhead and rents. The chance to combine the element of running our own bookstore with living in a self-sustainable manner into one cohesive vision is exceptionally rare. 

We’ve decided to focus on the underrepresented fringe genres of literature, allowing us to tap into a vein that’s long been ignored.

In specializing in fringe literature, The Road Virus will serve as a venue proving to be an outlier's dream. No longer will someone with a different worldview need to walk into a bookstore and immediately beeline for the back shelf consisting of one or two rows of books. Instead, amongst our shelves, you will find yourself literally surrounded by words and stories trained on releasing the darker parts of life.

Now, onto the main aspect of our vision for The Road Virus; horror. 

Even in the year of blockbuster hits like The Conjuring 2 and The Purge: Election Year grossing hundreds of millions of dollars in the box office, the broad genre of horror still remains to this day an underappreciated and trivialized one, especially in literary circles.

Horror as a genre is more of a subjective feeling rather than an objective and defined set of characteristics and the periodic successes that we see as a community owe a higher debt of gratitude to the visual rather than the written word.

Most people consume horror through movies and the occasional book. Then, there are people on the other side of the spectrum: those who themselves are consumed by horror.

When you think horror and household names, you think Stephen King, Edgar Allen Poe, Anne Rice, R.L. Stine, and H.P. Lovecraft. These are authors who are synonymous with the genre but don’t entirely encompass it.

The Road Virus strives to bring not only the critically acclaimed fan favorites but also esoteric and lesser known authors to horror-loving doorsteps around the US.

Throughout recent years, horror has had cyclical success on a broad scale which has brought attention and new fans to the genre; we want to give access to a wider variety and more specialized set of printed media.

Though our crosshairs are primarily centered on the terrifying, the spooky, and the generally off-putting, we will also set our sights on the following:

- science-fiction 
- spy/espionage thrillers 
- true crime
- fantasy 
- underground graphic novels/comics 
- queer studies/lit 
- modern poetry 
- underground film/music biographies & histories
- splatterpunk 
- erotica

and other fringe genres.

Another big aspect for us will be our children/YA section. Em, as a former YA librarian, has always been passionate about literacy in the younger crowd. Sade, a voracious reader from very early on, has always been obsessed with written words that could make him squirm.

Together, we believe that children deserve to be scared too. Some of our favorite children’s authors were ones that refused to hold our hands, those who believed that children shouldn’t be talked down to, and that they’re smarter and more resilient than common culture allows. We believe that society sometimes puts children into infantalized silos and tells them exactly how large their imaginations should be. We hope to help break that spell.

Our children's section will carry some of our personal childhood heroes such as R.L. Stine, John Bellairs, Roald Dahl, Edward Gorey, Shel Silverstein, Bruce Coville, and Christopher Pike.

Let's talk about community: the Road Virus wants to give back with more than just books. We are passionate about literacy above all else and want to reach the widest audience possible. 

Anyone of any age who feels like their reading level is not up to par can come by the Road Virus every Sunday from 10 AM - 4 PM and have private tutoring and free access to wi-fi to find other instructors in the area to continue their reading lessons. 

We believe that everyone deserves to read regardless of what kind of book interests them; we subscribe wholly to the ideal that whatever excites someone about reading is what is most important, be it horror, comic books, or Twilight (and everything in between). We will do our best to find a touchstone to teach literacy to an under-served community of non-readers wherever we go. 

Additionally, in our stretch goals, we would love to host free movie nights for every community we park in. Ideally, we will raise enough to purchase outdoor speakers to be mounted on The Road Virus, screen material, a projector, and some comfy seating. 

Our goal is to host a double-feature; the early show for kids/families and a later showing for adult audiences only. The former will appeal to people of all ages, with nostalgic classics such as Watership Down, The Halloween Tree, and The Addams Family. Sade has a storied background with movies that both get under your skin and in your skull, so for the adults, we'll be showing weird cult and horror classics as well as the fringe genres such as exploitation, Giallo, and terrible gory b-flicks. 

Again, horror and the subversive elements of written fiction have always been closely entwined with cinema; we endeavor to showcase that relationship. 

Onto why we're launching this Indiegogo: we have the goals, we have the drive, we have the experience; we just need help with the means. 

Unfortunately, our Kickstarter failed, which is why we're turning to a more lenient funding platform. 

In supporting our campaign, you are helping alleviate the following costs.

$7,500 - The bus itself. We just so happened to come across a devil's deal on Craigslist. Used for many years by Perry County (Indiana) as a bookmobile, the semi-converted retired schoolbus already has a history of promoting literacy. It includes built-in bookshelves, a generator that runs 110v electricity for lights/outlets, and a wheelchair lift, making us universally accessible. (We've already purchased the bus with a loan, so this portion is to pay it back.)

$1,000 - Rounding out the collection. We have a substantial collection of books in genres like scifi and thrillers already, but would like to specialize our stock to horror and hone in on granular subgenres and hard-to-find titles as much as possible. We plan to hit estate sales and other events across the US where books are bound to be. 

$2,000-$4,000 - Payment to a contractor for framing of a bathroom (and plumbing), self-contained kitchenette, and sleeping area. We will be living in The Road Virus full time, and so will require the basic necessities of home. We will also be installing skylights for more natural light throughout the bus. (We've done a huge amount of the legwork ourselves, going up to the buildsite every weekend to work on the bus). 

$1,000 - Fees, Paperwork, Insurance. Starting an LLC without a permanent address requires extensive tax paperwork and fees as well as insurance for the bus and ourselves. Permits in order to park in certain counties/states. Registering the bus. 

$1,000 - Full bus tuneup. Oil change, one tire replacement, transport/fuel from pickup (Missouri) to maiden voyage kickoff spot (California). During the drive back, there were a lot of unexpected costs. You can read about the trip here .

$1,500 - Basic appliances/fixtures. Fridge, toaster oven, sink, toilet, shower, electrical inverter, wi-fi hotspot. (We've purchased all of these except the toilet/shower/sink).

$5,000 - Exterior vinyl wrap for the bus. For us to stand out as a business and not just another RV or bus; so folks know what we are and why we're there. This is a pretty expensive process, and the quotes we've been getting are mostly in excess of $5,000.

While we recognize that our total costs are more than what we're asking for from the community, we hope that other book and horror lovers are generous in helping us reach and exceed our goal. 

Beyond the basics of mobile bookselling, we also want to offer additional services and features to set us apart from your typical retailer. Upon meeting our goals, we would also like to accomplish and incorporate the following into the store. 

Bus Upgrades: Conversion to veggie oil system and installation of solar panels and extra battery banks. 

Delivery service to your door: We'll purchase a motorized scooter and, for a small fee and within the local delivery area, we can bring your books directly to your door. 

Movie Nights: As described above, we'll purchase the required equipment to allow us to set up recurring movie nights with a double feature for kids and adults. 

Reading Is Infectious Book Club Subscription Service: Available in 3, 6, and 12 month subscriptions, we intend to offer three separate themed subscriptions to readers. You choose a length of time and a genre group and we'll send you one book per month for the length of your subscription. A great gift for the voracious reader in your life. 

Fringe Lit Online Community: On our website, we will be hosting a forum for lovers of fringe lit to come together and discuss the finer points of their favorite widely-unknowns. With the bus itself, we can reach communities across the US in person; through the forum, we hope to provide an outlet for people across the world. Click here to sign up for the forum.

Reading events for authors: In our travels and separate and joined communities, we've befriended many authors; we would like to give them a space to share their craft with their local community by hosting live readings, book signings, and other events. 

Typewriter podium: We want to bring out the writer in everybody; we'll have a typewriter set up in publicly accessible space to encourage creative expression. Type a poem, take a poem, leave a poem. 

Little Free Library: We'll have a Little Free Library set up on the outside of the bus. While these books might not always be on brand for The Road Virus, we'll make sure we always have a good selection. Just because you don't necessarily have the funds doesn't mean you have to leave without a book. 

Tiny animals for petting: What's a good bookstore without a few cute critters lying around? Right now, The Road Virus will be traveling with a small chihuahua named Fulci (named after the Italian director, famous for his gory Giallo films). We also intend to adopt a black cat; the chosen color due to the increased difficulty of finding homes for black cats because of the stigma surrounding them. We hope that our resident friends will bring a smile to our patrons' faces as well as encourage more casual browsing. Adopt, don't shop. 

To put things in terms of black and white - much like ink on a page - we are going to do this whether our campaign is fully-funded or not. 

Both of us have experience with small business ownership, from music publishing and distribution to library-inspired ephemera and jewelry-making. We know what it takes to start a small business, and to run it successfully; we understand the trials and tribulations which come with adversity in the small business market and selling wares to niche crowds.

Our biggest risk is that we have a single point of failure; our home, business, and vehicle will all be in one place. Because of this, we fully intend on sharpening our personal mechanical and general home-repair skills.

One of the biggest challenges facing independent bookstores these days is the advent and rapid growth of markets like Amazon where books are readily available and inexpensively shipped to your front door. 

We also recognize that horror, thrillers, sci-fi, and comic books might not be everyone's favorites and in some areas of the country they might even be downright unpopular - we hope to show that being scared is actually a good thing. Not only does it release endorphins and dopamine (which are "happiness hormones"), but being scared also releases oxytocin - a chemical produced by the brain that helps with human bonding. So pick up that next tempting creepy tome, because the family that scares together, stays together!

We believe that the experience of browsing a bookstore/sitting in a library is something that people, especially the younger generation, are lacking access to. There is a rich history and culture behind the personal human touch of bookselling that is being stripped down by the internet; with The Road Virus, we can combine the personal touch with the flexibility of setting up shop in communities across the US. 

As stated in our stretch goals, we want to offer door to door service in the future as well, giving even Amazon a slight run for their money.

story:
With 3 scheduled International exhibitions this year, my recent work is taking off fast. I can't complain. After being dedicated to filmmaking and architecture, I've decided to make it compatible with my old passion and I focused more in creative photography. And I believe the results are quite moving.  I'm obsessed building impossible spaces,  hypnotic perspectives and disruptive buildings coming from the future. 
 

The Perks

 

HD Wallpapers for PC, iPad and Mobile

A Quality Print 10 x 15 inches. Signed.

The Catalogue. Work in Progress. As a reference this is the catalog mockup for ESCAPE, a Marcelo von Schwartz exhibition in October 2017 in Bangkok.

A High Quality Printed Silk Neckerchief 20x20 inches

 

 

A High Quality Printed Silk Scarf 40x40 inches

 

A High Quality Art Print 2 available sizes, 20x30 and 40x60 inches. Signed series of 5.

 

A Letter From the Architect

After many vicissitudes in the last years with several films and architectural projects, I think it is time to focus again into the art circuit and return to show my works. I have rediscovered the passion for artistic photography - and for science fiction - and I have found the support of many people, friends and collectors who enjoy my works and feel that they produce "something" when they are looking at them.

My current challenge is to "build" futuristic-architectural visions of 4 Asian metropolis: Bangkok, Hong Kong, Tokyo and Shanghai. There will be 15-20 large-format photographs of each metropolis. Architecture and science fiction are again together for me.

The result will be exhibited at a traveling exhibition in art galleries in these four cities: in Bangkok the exhibition is confirmed at a wonderful art space in the heart of Bangkok, while galleries in Hong Kong, Tokyo and Shanghai are yet to be confirmed. The dates foreseen for the exhibition are during the first half of 2018.

The pictures will be published in a photo book, and a quality catalog will collect some of the most outstanding photographs.

I would like to receive support from people interested in my work and projects. Rather than offering a single big campaign, I think it is better to make a chain of "micro-campaigns", one to cover every step while I can frequently communicate to the people interested how the things are going , the trips, the challenges, how I see every city, the future of their architecture. How the project is going, how it is growing. I will be glad to get your feedback.

And a very important first step is to take my work and my project to Tokyo. My work was selected for the International Tokyo Art Fair on 26 and 27 May 2017. It will be an immense showcase and being there is very important to establish useful and necessary contacts for the future of the Metropolis Project.

Your support is very important for this project, since the costs of production are quite high.

In gratefulness to your interest and support I offer a collection of rewards with some of my works printed in different supports. Limited signed high-quality prints are also offered. And the catalog I'll print and take to Tokyo.

Let’s disrupt Tokyo together!

 

What Your Donations will Provide

$2000 - High Quality Printing and framing of 5 pictures 90x 90 cm

$1000 – Digital printing of 260 catalogs

$500 – 1 Round trip flight ticket Bangkok-Tokyo.

$300 – Additional shipping cost of 5 pictures and catalogs

$600 – 3 days in Tokyo, Hotel-Food-transportation

$1200 – fair fees and additional elements rental

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Here are few ideas:

Share this Indiegogo:  old fashioned word of mouth. It works!

Like and Share the Facebook Page:  I will really appreciate it! https://www.facebook.com/marcelovonschwartz/

Like and Share the Instagram Page: You will see some of my recent works https://www.instagram.com/marcelovonschwartz/?h...

Visit and Share the blog: Read more about the whole work in progress, see recent photos, take a look of some pictures and videos. Share it with friends https://vonschwartz.tumblr.com/

...And enjoy The Metropolis Project  Pinterest board https://in.pinterest.com/marcelovon/the-metropo...

Thank you!
story_txt:
With 3 scheduled International exhibitions this year, my recent work is taking off fast. I can't complain. After being dedicated to filmmaking and architecture, I've decided to make it compatible with my old passion and I focused more in creative photography. And I believe the results are quite moving.  I'm obsessed building impossible spaces,  hypnotic perspectives and disruptive buildings coming from the future.  
The Perks
 
HD Wallpapers for PC, iPad and Mobile


A Quality Print 10 x 15 inches. Signed.

The Catalogue. Work in Progress. As a reference this is the catalog mockup for ESCAPE, a Marcelo von Schwartz exhibition in October 2017 in Bangkok.
A High Quality Printed Silk Neckerchief 20x20 inches


 
 
A High Quality Printed Silk Scarf 40x40 inches


 
A High Quality Art Print 2 available sizes, 20x30 and 40x60 inches. Signed series of 5.

Other Ways You Can Help
Here are few ideas:

story:
Hi! I'm Yvette Mayorga an artist, raising money for my solo show at EXPO Chicago:


Budget:
The Fountainhead Residency: June 20- July 16th
EXPO Chicago: September 13-17

Art Supplies in Miami: $400
Transporting of work produced in Miami to Chicago: $500
Art Supplies in Chicago:

  • Frosting 4.5 Ib tub (12), to pipe the walls of the gallery at EXPO: $135
  • Disposable decorating bags (4): $30
  • Latex paint: $130
  • Custom wallpaper for EXPO: $500
  • 3 large Canvas for EXPO: $350
  • Flexible Modeling Paste, 3 gallons for paintings at EXPO: $300
  • Giveaway necklaces at EXPO: $300
  • Carpet for installation at EXPO 200 sq. ft: $400
  • Custom NEON SIGN: $300
  • Parking $30 a day x 3 days of install: $90
  • Hired helpers to install at $20/hr: $400
  • Fabricated objects: $1,115
  • Truck rental to move work to EXPO from studio: $50

Total Cost: $5000.00 

​I am happy to announce I have received a $1,000 in kind donation from a private donor, reducing my cost to $4,000.

My Story:

I am an interdisciplinary artist and daughter of Mexican immigrants. In my work, I use confection, industrial materials, and the American board game Candy Land as a conceptual framework to juxtapose the borderlands of the U.S. and Mexico. The spaces in the “Candy Lands” of my work relate to immigrant utopian visions of the American Dream.

I was recently invited to exhibit my work at EXPO Chicago this September 2017 as a solo show through my BOLT residency at The Chicago Artists Coalition, curated by Janine Mileaf. I also have been invited this summer to join The Fountainhead Residency in Miami, Florida curated by Jose Carlos Diaz, curator of the Andy Warhol Museum.

During our current political climate,  the opportunity to exhibit my work at EXPO Chicago, is an honor and privilege. It is a crucial time to insert the brown experience in the white cube space, specifically at a venue like EXPO that grants me the opportunity to exhibit at a national and international level. The opportunity to share my work about the immigrant experience with a broader audience will allow for a continuation of the conversation on the brown body politic in America.  My solo show at EXPO will be a continuation and expansion of my recent solo show at The Chicago Artists Coalition, "The Politics of Desire.” 

The Project

I will use my residency in Miami to create new work for my solo show at EXPO Chicago opening September 2017. During my stay in Miami I will be researching the similarities/differences between the immigrant communities of Miami and Chicago. On my return, in Chicago for EXPO, I will create a new body of work that deals with my father’s crossing of the U.S./Mexico border, by using recordings of conversations between my father and I that portray his detailed experience of crossing the border. Along with my father’s history, I will be implementing recent narratives of deportation and memories I have encountered as a teaching artist in Chicago. The new work will be a large scale immersive installation composed of paintings and sculptures including piping on the walls that will be reminiscent of a space found in the immigrants home.

The Impact

My goal as an artist is to continue to give voice to the immigrant experience through a feminist lens, retelling the story of my father’s struggle is a way to cultivate the real life experience of the American Dream. (https://thirdcoastreview.com/2017/03/13/yvette-...)

Within the last year, after completing my MFA at The School of the Art Insitute of Chicago in Fiber and Material Studies in May 2016, I have had the honor to show my work nationwide and across various cultural institutions in Chicago in 2017. This past March I showed work across 5 venues in two cities. Now, having the opportunity to show work at EXPO will only help push my career as an artist. Here is a list of recent and upcoming exhibitions:

Recent: The Vincent Price Art Museum, The School of the Art Institute of Chicago, The National Museum of Mexican Art, University of Indianapolis, The Chicago Artists Coalition, The Chicago Cultural Center, and Roots and Culture 

Upcoming: "Out of Easy Reach," at Gallery 400, "The Petty Biennial," at The Arts Incubator, and "Bold Disobedience," at Weinberg and Newton Gallery.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word!

Use the hashtags with love: #SendYvettetoExpo  #YvetteXexpo #ExpoNeedsYvette

With Love & Solidarity,

Yvette Mayorga

Upcoming: "Out of Easy Reach," at Gallery 400, "The Petty Biennial," at The Arts Incubator, and "Bold Disobedience," at Weinberg and Newton Gallery.
 
 

Other Ways You Can Help
Please help spread the word!
Use the hashtags with love: #SendYvettetoExpo  #YvetteXexpo #ExpoNeedsYvette
With Love & Solidarity,
Yvette Mayorga

story:
Who We Are

For 19 years, CulturalDC’s mission has been to “Make Space for Art.” We've brokered over 250,000 square feet of space working with real estate developers, artists, city officials, residents, and other key stakeholders through creative placemaking initiatives, community-centered engagements, and innovative real estate partnerships. Our efforts have resulted in the creation of Atlas Performing Arts Center, Source Theatre, Brookland Arts Lofts, and the 27 artist studios at Monroe Street Market in Brookland.

 

Our Mission

Space4: Art is a new initiative that will continue our strong history of presenting cutting edge artwork and emerging artists through a mobile container gallery. Space4: Art allows artists to transform a fully-outfitted 40ft shipping container into an immersive environment. The container will move across the city for the 2017-2018 season, with a new exhibit and free community events in every neighborhood it visits.

Also embracing a mobile strategy next season, CulturalDC's Space4: Performing Arts initiative will bring innovative performance experiences to unexpected venues across the city, like Blind Whino SW Arts Club and Dupont Underground. 

 

Why We Need Your Help

We can't accomplish our goal alone. The process of taking our white walls mobile has a lot of up front costs we need help covering. Every dollar contributed to our $10,000 goal will go directly to the build out of our shipping container. Here's everything we'll need to do in order to get our container up to art gallery standards:

  • Purchase and move the container
  • Paint the outside and inside
  • Install flooring, track lighting, and gallery walls
  • Outfit the container with an HVAC system for heating and cooling
  • Purchase and place solar panels on the roof so the gallery can run off the grid

 

What You Get

We're offering some pretty rad perks in exchange for your campaign contributions. Check out the different levels of incentives on our page. Want to create your own art installation inspired by Roo's glitter artwork in the video? We've got your personalized glitter bomb! Want a limited edition art print by one of the artists in our inaugural Space4: Art season? We've got you covered. Want to host your own event in the container? There's even a level for that.

Beyond the perks, you are also taking an active role in fostering the arts community in Washington, DC. CulturalDC would not be where we are today without the continued support of our community. We work hard everyday to ensure we're providing the best programming possible so that arts can flourish across the District. 

 

Thank you!

If you're as excited about our campaign as we are, help spread the word! Use the icons at the top of the page to share our campaign on social media. And don't forget to use #Space4Art!

Follow CulturalDC on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram for updates about the campaign and for information on our visual and performing arts programming - you won't want to miss our 2017-2018 seasons.

With your support, we can make space for art right in your neighborhood!

story:
Short Summary

Argha Noah is an artist-run civic engagement platform that transforms unused urban spaces into showcases for innovation in art, music, education, urban agriculture, and recreation.  We've been granted Harp Transmission, a shuttered mechanic shop in downtown Atlanta, as the site of our first season of community-oriented programming, and we need your help to bring the space up to snuff and to pay our incredible artists and program instructors!

So - what kind of programs does Argha Noah offer Atlanta?

As a forum for exciting reflections on the future and critical reconsiderations of Atlanta’s past, Argha Noah will play host to workshops, lectures, art exhibitions, film screenings, community dinners, weekend farmers markets, concerts, and even pick-up basketball games. Our programs and events fall under five categories: art, music, education, recreation, and agriculture.

Our events will grant artists, urban strategists and community members an opportunity to both enjoy enriching programs, and break bread with civic organizations producing innovative solutions to the Atlanta’s most pressing problems.

Argha Legend

1. Main exhibition space/Indoor venue

2. Community resources/workspace

3. Argha Noah design studio

4. Basketball court

5. Pop-up concession space

6. Grand amphitheater

7. City Park

8. Flex-use outdoor space

9. Community Garden

 

 

The Bigger Picture - or, why our work is important.

With each edition of Argha Noah, we advance a holistic, inclusive model of cultural & technological exchange that imparts both practical knowledge and creative sustenance to a host community.

And in partnering with artists, city officials, and community stakeholders to create 21st century civic spaces, the Argha Noah model changes a region’s development narrative from one based on developer profits, expedience, and non-native interests to one that upholds health, sustainability, and access to the arts as fundamental urban utilities.

And while Atlanta is spoiled for art, culture, and amazing people producing extraordinary work in scholarship, art, and activism, our decentralized urban character often keeps these voices apart. Argha Noah will function not only as a hub for people to discover one another but as a platform for world-class events our neighbors may not have access to otherwise.

What We Need & What You Get

Our fundraising goal is $25,000. Here's where your money will go:

  • Crucial renovations to the site, including a good deep clean, new electrical wiring, some leak fixes, and a fresh coat of paint. We're starting with an abandoned car shop and have a long way to go to make the space inviting and safe for visitors.
  • Furniture - from tables and chairs for community workshops to simple, flexible walls and track lighting for art exhibitions.
  • Geodesic half-dome stage - for outdoor concerts and lectures.
  • Paying our artists and staff. We're taking a stand against rampant exploitation in the creative industry by pledging to pay the artists we commission to produce work for us! We believe there should be no excuse, however small our organization and however big our dreams may be! Your contribution helps us stand up against precarious labor practices.
  • Building materials, soil, and seeds for our community garden.

If we meet our fundraising goal, we can afford to make 90% of our events free to the public. The less money we raise, the less accessible our programming will be - so we're super motivated to raise as much as we can so that we may to reach the most people possible!

Alright, alright. So what do you get out of it?

Unique perks:

  • Founding member credit on website
  • Limited edition postcards
  • Limited edition T-shirt + Zine
  • Argha Noah golden tickets (Two tickets to a special event of your choice)
  • Pitch an IDEA! Three minute pitches from the community
  • Sponsorship signage on website
  • Sponsorship signage on website + interactive amphitheater

The Impact

Though each edition of Argha Noah is temporary, programming and events are designed to spur growth and connections long past the duration of our residency. We want to start a movement, and we believe that begins with sharing common space.

We're using the space to inspire Atlanta with:

  • Fresh Knowledge
  • New Friendship
  • Contemporary Experiences

This is about envisioning a vibrant and socially responsible future together!

Risks & Challenges

The Argha Noah team is running on a tight schedule to get our space open. We only have the space until the end of the year, and we want to offer as many events as possible until then. But there's a lot to finish before we invite the community into our space.

Our biggest challenges include:

  • Indoor renovations
  • Outdoor renovations
  • Material supplies

These things rely on funding and volunteer support. We've been able to start the renovation process with our own team and funding, but we hope to kick things into a higher gear with outside support.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We need plenty of other things besides just funding. The site still needs a lot of work, and we're busy every day preparing.  You can help us bring Argha Noah to Atlanta by:

  • Volunteering- help clean the building or set-up an event 
  • Donating materials- we need building and workshops materials; furniture would be great, too!  
  • Sharing our story- it's a temporary space, so we want to get the word out fast

Of course, you can also support Argha Noah by attending events! We can't wait to share the journey with you this Summer.

story:
VERSÃO EM PORTUGUÊS

Hi, my name is Paulo Abrantes, I am a photographer and I was invited by The Brick Lane Gallery to be part of the group exhibition LANDSCAPE; RURAL VS URBAN, that will take place in London from the 12th  - 25th of April 2016.

LANDSCAPE; RURAL VS URBAN questions our interpretation of landscapes and different sceneries through the appreciation of nature on its own and the exploration of man intervened urban settings. The show brings together a vibrant range of local and international artists who focus on the different ways we relate to the places we inhabit and the impact we have on them.

Photos available for the exhibition

The Brick Lane Gallery  is located in the creative art district of east London, in Brick Lane.

Brick Lane is not only a very lively and popular location for art and culture, it is also just a few steps away from the financial district. Brick Lane is also one of the most popular areas in the city of London for Street Art.

The possibility of presenting my work in a privileged setting for cultural events gives continuity to the internationalisation of my work that had started in Rio de Janeiro (Brazil) and later in Spain, through the Zamora and Salamanca Museums.

This is, without a doubt, an interesting visibility opportunity. But, there are costs involved, costs that are unavailable at this moment. Only through an advanced support, through the sale of the photographs that will be exhibited, or through other offers that give you the possibility to also be part of this exhibition in London.

1 €

Thank You for Your Support!

Your name will be included in the list of acknowledgments of the exhibition in the gallery.


7 €

E-MAGAZINE

You will receive an online magazine about the exhibition, installation and set-up, opening reception, moments of the journey and images of London, to be sent by electronic mail.

PDF and Flash format - Size 31,5x22,5 cm - 68 Pages


11 €

POSTCARD

You will receive, by post, a personalised postcard, sent from London.

Limited to 50 postcards.


33 €

E-BOOK

You will receive, by electronic mail, an e-book of the photographs included in the exhibition, book of photographs in digital format.


PDF and Flash format - Size 16.5x24cM - 32 Pages


77 €

PHOTOGRAPH 30x30 cm

(From the photos available for the exhibition)

Limited edition of the 8 photographs

Printed in Bamboo 290 GSM - Hahnemühle 5 photographic paper

Wooden frame


111 €

PHOTOGRAPH 40x30 cm

(From the photos available for the exhibition)

Limited edition of the 16 photographs

Printed in Bamboo 290 GSM - Hahnemühle 5 photographic paper

Wooden frame

-  Postcards: April, during the exhibition

-  E-Magazine: May

-  E-Book: June

-  Photographs: May

Even if you are not available for an offer, I understand that we live in times of crisis, you can also collaborate with the promotion of this campaign. How? Simply by sharing this campaign in your social media (Facebook, Twitter, etc.). Your sharing of the link will be a huge support. I thank you for your attention, contribution and sharing.

Paulo Abrantes was born in Luanda, Angola, on the 11th of February, 1969.

story:
Boto-cor-de-rosa: books, art and coffee

Boto-cor-de-rosa is an independent bookstore in Salvador, Bahia in the northeastern region of Brazil. The name literally translates as “pink dolphin,” the charming and irresistible figure of many Brazilian folkoric legends. At the Boto, we believe that providing the physical space and opportunity to interact with books helps to inspire the pleasure of reading and also supports independent and local venders whose productions are generally squandered by megastores and virtual domains in Brazil.

Within a region and culture where few Brazilians enjoy reading and where the only bookstores in the city are owned by two large franchises, the Boto is not one among many fish in the sea—it is the only independent bookstore in all of Salvador, the third largest city in Brazil. The Boto is the vision of two determined and creative women and a tale of bringing together local writers, adult and young readers, intellectuals, presses and those curious enough to read a poem for the very first time. We invite you to read our story and support us in our fight to keep the Boto’s doors open.

In a place where few Brazilians enjoy picking up a book, the Boto provides a physical space for literary lovers and curious first-timers to read, play and interact with books. Brazil's northeast faces some of the greatest challenges to improving literacy. Educational disadvantages are unquestionably marked by class and race—the northeast is the poorest region in Brazil and Salvador is also home to the largest population of people from the African Diaspora outside of Africa. But even among those who do read, understanding the pleasure of literature as a source of imagination, possibility, provocation, and expression has yet to really take form—70 percent of Brazilians do not read a single book during the entire year (Fecomércio RJ 2012). For many, their understanding of literature is limited to required school readings of the classics. And those who want to go to a bookstore only have the option of walking into big shopping malls where franchise bookstores and megastores are dominated by large publishing companies and the winners of national literary prizes (the majority of which are male writers from Brazil’s southeastern metropolises). Rarely do Bahians and other Brazilians see their vibrant imaginations and histories reflected in these literary displays. But two women, along with several friends and volunteers along the way, have created a space that through books, art and community has realized a cultural, social and political vision.

Two women at the front of the Boto’s vision and charm

         

Milena Britto has spent her entire life and career dedicated to expanding the spaces, resources and initiatives available for literary production and experiences. She has worked closely with social movements, collaborated with poetry slam initiatives and organized literary workshops throughout the country. She is a university literature professor in Bahia and witnesses every day how hard it is for youth and adults to get excited about reading and the barriers they face in gaining access to diverse literary possibilities. Milena also previously worked for the state Department of Culture, where she saw the challenges that local writers (especially women) and small presses face in gaining support from the broader literary landscape. Throughout all of these different adventures, conversations with artists, publishers, intellectuals, students, dedicated readers and those who had never opened a book before, Milena began to dream of opening a bookstore—a space in Salvador where people could interact with one another, share ideas, engage in political debates and develop a relationship with books through both the imaginations they inspire as well as their physicality. But making this dream a reality required finding the resources as well as the right partner who shared her passion and vision.

Sarah Rebecca Kersley, a poet born in the United Kingdom, has been resident in Brazil for the past twelve years. She lived and worked in the interior of Bahia for several years, where she opened a small bookstore (before the Boto) to try to share her passion for reading in a city with no other bookstore and also not a single public library. But with low literacy levels and few customers, it became too tough to stay open. Sarah’s passion for poetry and Brazilian contemporary literature eventually took her to Bahia’s capital of Salvador, a move that quickly led to an encounter of literary passions, experience and visions.

Sarah scraped together all of her savings and joined forces with Milena as curator to make the Boto a reality. After months of pushing through the challenges of finding a space, making the necessary renovations (while fighting against all of the machismo that came with that), learning barista techniques, meticulously selecting the first titles to stock, and collecting enough espresso cups and sofa pillows to welcome people in, they finally opened the doors of the Boto to the public in May 2015.

The Boto’s vision – contemporary literature, shared space and a local community

Since its opening, the Boto has won over the heart of the city. It is a free-standing shop with an outdoor sign of a dolphin tail that sways from a rebellious tree branch jutting into the sidewalk. This cozy space welcomes Boto regulars and curious passers by with coffee and treats primarily made by local venders—from the organic coffee beans from the Chapada Diamantina National Park to the fresh tarts and pastries made by local independent producers. Since its opening, the Boto has become essential to the community—from being a safe reading space (of which there are very few here), to a place for children and youth to develop an early love for reading, a resource for contemporary literature and poetry, a space for lively readings and book launches, and a site for debate and political discussion. Many people spend hours flipping through books, sharing how excited they are to have a place to read and chat that isn’t inside a shopping mall. Others walk in as they stroll along the street with a clear expression of confusion...having never seen a bookstore along the street (or anywhere else) with novels, poetry, theory texts, children's books, and an espresso machine, many come to learn what a bookstore is for the first time.

The Boto walls, shelves and coffee tables are full of various forms of contemporary literature. But you won’t find many commercial “bestsellers”, since this product already has its niche and readers. The Boto seeks projects that challenge literary language (in the plural sense of “literary”) and avoids the cliché and obvious--this is true both for our adult and children selections. It also displays contemporary texts from other areas (philosophy, gender and sexuality, race and ethnicity, political science, anthropology, interdisciplinary studies, cultural studies). Our display always has an excellent selection of local literature and publishing presses and the criteria are the same as those used for our whole curation process. The displays  highlight many of Brazil’s underrepresented female writers and poets, as well as indigenous, Afro-Brazilian, and queer literatures that are often ignored by the megastores. But a book won’t be in stock just because it’s from the local scene— “Bahian” literature for us is held to the same standards as Brazilian literature. In other words, the Boto seeks to challenge the marginalization of these literatures by highlighting the fact that they are muted in spite of their excellent literary and aesthetic quality.

The Boto supports small and independent presses to enter the broader literary landscape and also shares contemporary literature from throughout the globe to its local readers. We follow contemporary debates, discussions and literary launches in  diverse themes and forms not just from Latin America, but also other continents. 

      

Yes, we are not-for-profit

In spite of its legal status as a business, the Boto's mission is not-for-profit. We submitted our application to be legally recognized as not-for-profit over six months ago, however, legal and bureaucratic processes are unfortunately very slow in Bahia, especially for gaining this type of organizational status. So, we're being transparent here--formally, we're a business, but not in it at all for the profit and are doing everything possible to get official recognition for that. In the meantime, we sincerely hope you'll help us keep our community's bookstore open. 

The Boto needs your help!

Brazil is currently experiencing its worst recession since the 1930s and Brazilians' severe economic concerns have impacted their lives and that of the Boto in a very real way. The space used to be full of people throughout the day and packed for evening book launches, poetry readings and art shows. But in the past few months the Boto has passed days without having one customer.It's become very difficult to cover even basic costs (electricity, water, rent) and the Boto will likely not be able to stay open for much longer without some support.

The funds from this campaign will allow us to achieve the following:

  • Cover expenses for the next three months: rent, electricity, water and payment to local vendors.

  • Pay salaries for our two part-time Boto helpers.

  • Cover payment for bookstocks provided by our local presses. 

  • Use the next three months to organize workshops and events that will allow the Boto to again be self-sustaining.

  • Run not-for-profit workshops with local artists (this brings in more community members and also supports artists during an especially difficult economic/political moment). 

  • Keep open a literary and cultural space that resists recent political changes that are devastating to literary production and the representation of women, Afro-Brazilian, indigenous and queer artists. 

The very big impact of your support

While the recession has made it very difficult to stay open, keeping the Boto afloat could not be more critical in the current political moment. Democratically elected President Dilma Rousseff has been usurped by interim conservative president Michel Temer, who has already made several changes that are devastating to the cultural domain and social policies. He has abolished the federal Ministry of Culture and the Ministry of Women, Racial Equality and Human Rights resulting in a dramatic halt to government support for cultural initiatives. Fighting to keep open cultural spaces could not be more critical—our campaign to keep the Boto running isn’t just about keeping alive the vision of two inspiring women, but about bringing together and strengthening a diverse community that creates a far-reaching solidarity through cultural creativity and expression that resists the efforts to stifle that very spirit!

story:
Synopsis

Sean's life is on the line as he learns that he is a major suspect in a crime committed in a Brooklyn apartment, where he went to make a delivery.  His best friend and mother are the only two people, who despite circumstantial evidence, don't believe Sean had anything to do with the crime. They feel that the main culprit behind the incident has everything to do with Mike, the neighborhood hustler, who has been protecting Sean and few others that live on his block.  Now Sean's life and future college plans will be on the line, as other, including his lawyer, must work to prove his incense. 

What this Campaign Is All About

Looking At A Second Chance is a short film written by Shelly Christian.  The short script was entered into two well know film festivals, which both work showcase a diverse scripts and films.  Looking at a Second chance, The screen-play received a warm welcome in California at the Action on Film Festival. In October it will be at the Urban Media Makers, Film Festival in Atlanta.  This campaign will help turn the written script into a visual body of work, and will cover both the production and post production cost. 

First Tier Goal- $2,000
Second Tier Goal- $2,500
Third Tier Goal- $3,000

What We Need & What You Get

The Screen-play, Looking At A Second Chance touches on current day social issues,,  within underprivileged communities that affects youth, teachers, and families across the board.

The Impact

The goal of this film is to promote diversity in the film industry, by creating a platform for underrepresented performers. It is also to bring forth a  storyline which  is sometimes mis-told in mainstream films.  By supporting, you are a major part of a movement to help diversify the stories and individuals represented in this industry.

Risks & Challenges

As a first time filmmaker having the right team is important along with creating the exact vision, in order to create this finished project. This is why funding is so  imortant for the success of this film.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to invest, no fret:

  • Feel free to pass this link around to get the word out, every bit of awareness and contribution is important to the success of this project :-)

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Who Am I?

My name is Don Scully, and I am not your average entrepreneur. You may have heard similar pitches before, but I truly believe my project is unique! The facts are, that I am a collector, who happens to know my passion for reasonably priced vintage art makes good business sense. There is a surprisingly large market for vintage art. I say surprising because I got involved in collecting vintage art prints for fun, but the further I looked into it, I realised just how massive the business is. I had a great time indulging myself in this pastime, so when I moved to Malaga in 2003, I became totally immersed in the artistic culture, which is an obvious side effect of living in the city best known as the birth place of Picasso!

My Venture

As a result of my love of art, I studied how pieces are bought and sold. It can be a pricey pursuit and consequently many collectors are quite wealthy. I am not in that bracket, but I nurtured the idea for people in my category (that of the average Joe) having access to these beautiful items that the better off enjoy. So, I created Art of Class. I have traded for over ten years here in Spain, and currently I sell on Etsy. I am however, in the process of building a stand alone website for Art of Class that allows purveyors of art to explore and shop without breaking the bank or spending their child's education fund.

I also understand the importance of mobile shopping today.  With tablets and smartphones as the norm, most people no longer sit at the computer to purchase goods.  They are constantly on the go.  So, I came up with "Único", a Tinder type app for purchasing exclusive YET affordable art! The app will be available through Google Play, and my long term goal includes adding other unique stores to the app in future, to make a shopping experience like no other.

Your Part

I am currently at a crossroads.  I need help financing the project, or the project ends here. 

This is obviously close to my own heart, however, i know it will help other small business entrepreneurs also in the long run.  I am asking the following:

1. If you can spare even ten pounds, every little helps! 

2. EVERYBODY who donates receives something in return, and those who contribute more than five pounds will be the recipient of 'at least' the value they have put in - see Perks column.

3. Whether you can donate or not, I ask that you share my project with your social network and circles of influence.  The more people that are aware of the project, the more people can help it succeed.

As always, thank you for your continued support.
story_txt:
Who Am I?
My name is Don Scully, and I am not your average entrepreneur. You may have heard similar pitches before, but I truly believe my project is unique! The facts are, that I am a collector, who happens to know my passion for reasonably priced vintage art makes good business sense. There is a surprisingly large market for vintage art. I say surprising because I got involved in collecting vintage art prints for fun, but the further I looked into it, I realised just how massive the business is. I had a great time indulging myself in this pastime, so when I moved to Malaga in 2003, I became totally immersed in the artistic culture, which is an obvious side effect of living in the city best known as the birth place of Picasso!

My Venture
As a result of my love of art, I studied how pieces are bought and sold. It can be a pricey pursuit and consequently many collectors are quite wealthy. I am not in that bracket, but I nurtured the idea for people in my category (that of the average Joe) having access to these beautiful items that the better off enjoy. So, I created Art of Class. I have traded for over ten years here in Spain, and currently I sell on Etsy. I am however, in the process of building a stand alone website for Art of Class that allows purveyors of art to explore and shop without breaking the bank or spending their child's education fund.
I also understand the importance of mobile shopping today.  With tablets and smartphones as the norm, most people no longer sit at the computer to purchase goods.  They are constantly on the go.  So, I came up with "Único", a Tinder type app for purchasing exclusive YET affordable art! The app will be available through Google Play, and my long term goal includes adding other unique stores to the app in future, to make a shopping experience like no other.

Your Part
I am currently at a crossroads.  I need help financing the project, or the project ends here. 
This is obviously close to my own heart, however, i know it will help other small business entrepreneurs also in the long run.  I am asking the following:
1. If you can spare even ten pounds, every little helps! 
2. EVERYBODY who donates receives something in return, and those who contribute more than five pounds will be the recipient of 'at least' the value they have put in - see Perks column.
3. Whether you can donate or not, I ask that you share my project with your social network and circles of influence.  The more people that are aware of the project, the more people can help it succeed.
As always, thank you for your continued support.

story:
Der Benni Skate Tisch

Benni ist die Möglichkeit für junge, urbane Menschen, ihrem Zuhause ein neues Lebensgefühl zu spendieren. Der Tisch mit seinem innovativen Design und hochwertigen Materialien wertet jedes Wohnzimmer auf und passt auch perfekt in Deine Wohnung. Wir sind überzeugt, dass der Benni nicht nur in unseren Wohnzimmern gut aussieht, und möchten darum jedem die Gelegenheit geben sich einen anzuschaffen.


Wer wir sind

Wir, das sind Max, Marc und Leon, die Gründer von Benni.

          

Wir haben uns während des Studiums kennen gelernt und unsere gemeinsame Begeisterung für innovatives urbanes Design entdeckt. Aus dieser Begeisterung ist nach kurzer Zeit die Idee für den Benni entstanden, den wir Euch über die Plattform Crowdfunding anbieten wollen.

Unser Ziel

Zunächst ist die Kampagne unser Hauptvertriebskanal. Dadurch können wir mit geringem Aufwand so viele Menschen wie möglich erreichen und den Kauf des Benni vereinfachen. Mit dem verdienten Geld wollen wir den Benni noch weiter verbessern und einen eigenen Online Shop aufbauen.
Unser Ziel ist es insgesamt 6.000 € einzusammeln. Der Großteil dieses Geldes wird für Materialbeschaffung der verkauften Tische verwendet. Da jeder Tisch individuell nach Deinen Vorstellungen angefertigt wird, haben wir entsprechend hohe Fertigungskosten. Zusätzlich zu der Möglichkeit den Benni zu bestellen, haben wir uns verschiedene Perks ausgedacht, die wir unseren Unterstützern zuschicken.

Produktdetails

Der Benni ist ein dreibeiniger Tisch aus Massivholz. Wir bieten die drei Holzarten Birke, Eiche und Nuss an, damit der Benni optimal in euere Wohnung passt. Auf den Tischbeinen sind Skateboardachsen verschraubt, sodass die Tischplatte aus Glas auf den Rollen der Achsen aufliegt. Die Achsen liefern wir wahlweise in silber, weiss, rot und blau. Durch die Skateboardrollen ergibt sich der innovative Effekt, dass die Platte sich drehen lässt.
Der Tisch ist (inklusive Glasplatte) 43 cm. hoch. Die Platte hat einen Durchmesser von 80 cm. Sie steht dadurch leicht über den Rand des Holzgestells hinaus.

Maße



Achsenfarben

Holzarten

Birke

Eiche

Nuss

Wie könnt Ihr uns unterstützen?

Wenn euch der Benni genauso gut gefällt wie uns, dann helft uns mehr Leuten von uns zu erzählen. Ihr findet uns auch auf Facebook, Twitter, Instagram und Pinterest.

story:
Hey! My name's Jesús and I'm a circus artist, who greatly enjoys doing tricks and hanging about in the air. I specialise in aerial straps. But I also practice slakcline, and recently had a revelation during my training.

Initially these two circus disciplines don't have anything in common. Not until I realised the equipment of both practices looks nearly the same. There it came the idea of using the same prop for both specialities.

However, aerial straps uses the material in a vertical position, and hanging from the ceiling. Slackline uses a strap as well, but this time in the horizontal, and attached to two points in both extremes, like a couple of trees. So... how could we possibly bring the two together?

We need a structure. A structure that allows the same strap to be placed in any position: vertical; horizontal; and even more excitingly, in any degree of inclination, bringing new possibilities for discovery and development of the practice.

Jeffrey is in charge of the design and build of the new creature. He is a designer and a mechanical engineer; so yes, you guess well thinking he's a wicked genius.

We need to gather enough money to pay for the materials and costs of the construction. These materials need to be of best quality to ensure safety standards are met. But also light, to improve mobility and reduce fuel and transport costs.

The creation of this structure will also take us into a greater journey, where we will develop a show. We will also need as much help as possible for this period. So getting to a good start is essential, and could guarantee a much more powerful future.

We believe in people’s power to make beautiful and daring things happen. If you like our ideas, please support us. No worries if you can’t help with money, but we’d be really grateful if you can help spreading the voice. You can use the Indiegogo sharing tools! Or most efficiently, finding your own ways, and using the good old fashioned word of mouth.

Many many thanks :)

story:
What is this?

Consumer VR has arrived and we've been treated to some sleek, high quality designs from Samsung and Oculus. Now, despite the fantastic looks of these HMDs, there will always be that desire to make a product your own. With VRface, we want to give everyone the ability to add their own unique flair to upcoming VR headsets like the Oculus Rift and the Samsung GearVR.

What We Need & What You Get

Funds to buy manufacturing materials/tools, and you get dope stickers.

The Impact

Guys, it looks cool. Why not, you know.

Risks & Challenges

If the demand is unexpectedly high (which I doubt) or there are unforeseen issues (life happens and such), there could be delays of a couple weeks (maximum of 2-4).  I rather under-promise than oversell what is possible/likely. Thank you for your patience in advance! :)

Other Ways You Can Help

Be nice, share on social media, and/or reddit?

story:
Hi! I'm Marauder! I'm a professional alternative model who has been modeling for 12 years. I am experienced, versatile, and reliable. I always bring my all to shoots. Lately I've been embarking on the exciting journey of modeling full time. It's been a hell of a trip, and sometimes it's been great, other times not so much. The best way to keep with modeling is to embark on tours to other states and locations in order to  book and work with new photographers along the way, so that's what I've decided to do along with my modeling companion, Astrid Von Winter.

This summer, we're setting our sites on a month long tour to the  West Coast. This is both exciting and terrifying, as we're looking at a month on the road touring to brand new locations and working with new people. It can be really exciting, but it also leaves room for plenty to stress about. 

The thing with touring, is you book work, but it doesn't mean people won't cancel at last minute, and this tends to be one of those looming issues. There's also the chance that the person you're staying with in certain states will decide against it, or car troubles will ensue 0.o (the worst fear 0.0). 

All this aside, the car we are embarking on this tour with still needs a new tag and insurance on it. I don't think it will be a problem since we have two months to get our things together for the tour, but it's still a looming stress that would be nice to put aside.

Unfortunately, this year money is tight. I've embarked on the adventure of opening up a studio with a fellow photographer, and new businesses are more of a drain on the income than profitable until you get them going. All of my focus has been on this, and booking paid shoots has been difficult since my car has no tag or insurance. So, I'm in limbo, I need money to get the tag and title, but I need the car to make money. Isn't that fantastic? ;D

Once we get touring, things will be a lot easier, but until that time, any help that can be given is super appreciated .

ANYWAYS, enough about me. Here's the cool benefits that come with donating.

I'm offering different levels of rewards for each donation. I understand that everyone is going to have different wants and needs, so I'm going to try to offer something for everyone, from photographers to fans. 

I have a LARGE collection of all of my nude photoshoots on my computer. One of the big prizes will be an invite to a dropbox folder hosting all of my work, erotic, fetish, nude, you name it. It's like the Masturbator's Guide to the Galaxy (why is this not a porno mag anyways?)

I'm offering signed prints of the photos of your choice, check out my facebook for some of the options, or message me with a request
Facebook.com/xmarauderx 

I'm offering custom shoots! Want me to dress like  a school girl and do a strip tease? Can do. Want me to dress like Pikachu for your Pokemon fetish? Why not. I've heard weirder. Want an entire set of my feet? Not a problem. Like I said, versatile, and totally not judgmental of your sexual deviance ;D

Want personal effects? I have so much lingerie and underwear, I actually could really stand to get rid of quite a lot of it. Hit me up with what you're looking for, we can make it happen!

Want to have a Skype chat? We can do that! (No sexual favors yo), but I'm not against playing Truth or Dare, Never Have I Ever, or Strip Hangman on Skype either. 

Want to book a shoot before or during my tour? If you book via my indiegogo, I'm offering MAD DISCOUNTS for shooting. 

Want something not listed? Rad, let me know. Let's make this shit happen!

I listed the goal as 1000, but I'd be happy to get halfway to that goal. Anything you can contribute helps, even if all you can do is share it along.

What's more?

I'm working on building a password protected blog or site of sorts for the trip. I'll post some stuff publicly, but the blog will basically include any NSFW photos taken, exclusive videos, photos, and BTS stuff, and anyone who donates will get a link and password before the tour for you to access exclusive content.

So say you're just like, what the hell, here's $5 Marauder. You'll get whatever prize goes with the donation amount, plus access to the blog that's for Indiegogo Donors only! (how about that?) All I need is your EMAIL ADDRESS (so make sure you list it, I'm unfortunately not psychic and can't figure these things out for myself....curses.)

Anyways, if you can share this, you're awesome. If you can donate, you're even more awesome. If you can donate AND share, then you're like a unicorn that shoots billions of dollars out of it's horn and vomits watermelon margaritas.

story:
What is About Water?

Photographers Jasmine Amara & Jen Fedrizzi will be visiting communities throughout California for three weeks in the summer of 2017 with a traveling photo exhibition. The exhibition will show how water management between Los Angeles and the Owens Valley has significantly reshaped the land and human relationship with water. Our vision is to take what we have learned on the Walking Water pilgrimage and beyond to share and educate others through photographs and storytelling. By sharing our photographs, we hope to inspire a shift in the way our society relates to water. We desire to see movement from a culture that consumes more than we have, drying up entire lakes and destroying ecosystems, to one that honors water and the life she creates. 

Walking Water is a three year, three phase pilgrimage that explores our relationship to water to understand how our decisions have changed the landscape, ecosystems and culture. We will be learning from a diverse group of locals and global citizens, including natives, activists, artists, and local and global educators. We will be observing and learning to understand what we can do as a society to better care for water so there is enough for the land, ourselves and other life forms for generations to come.

In the fall of 2015,  we embarked on the first phase of Walking Water and will walk again in the fall of 2016. Phase two of the pilgrimage will travel another 200 miles on foot from Owens Lake to Sylmar, CA. 



Who Are We?

Jasmine Amara Beaghler​

 I believe art is an incredibly powerful tool for healing, connection and education. I am an artist dedicated to using creativity as a way to reshape destructive beliefs and practices. This last year I have had the opportunity to work on several projects regarding water including, Walking Water and To Dust

 

Jen Fedrizzi

I am a photographer and activist using my camera as a life long creative partner to tell stories I cannot express into words. I focus my energy on connection, deep listening, community, healing and love in all aspects of my life. I am committed to learning, educating and engaging with others to be of service to local and global communities.


What It Will Take to Make It Possible

Your kind generosity will help us achieve our goal. We offer the following cost breakdown to share with you where the donations will be applied within this project. 


Walking Water fund + Equipment ~ $3,500

Production costs ~ $5000

Equipment Insurance ~$1000

Print + Framing costs ~ $3500

Photo stands ~ $500

Travel/lodging ~ $1700

Food ~ $900 

Marketing/incentives ~ $1000

Indiegogo costs ~ $900

Total: $18,000


Our travels will bring us throughout many counties in California including Inyo, Sonoma, San Francisco, Ventura, Los Angeles, and Orange County.


Your Impact

"Water is not a commodity: it is life itself and it needs to be respected."

-Michael Prather of Lone Pine, Calif.

There is much happening with our waters locally and globally. From fracking to drought to mismanaged waterways and beyond. The state and health of our water is being compromised for our current and future generations.

We invite you in supporting this campaign and those alike. You will be directly helping make an impact in individual perspectives of our precious life source.


Other Ways to Help

We understand that one may not be able to gift a financial contribution and we empathize. That doesn't mean there is not space to make a contribution in a different way. 

The simplest way you can help is by taking a moment to share our campaign with your community! Any method of sharing goes a long way, whether it be by phone, word of mouth, text, email, postcard, or, most importantly, social media! Indiegogo provides these lovely tools to make sharing easy on your social platforms. 

If you like to get involved check out Walking Water or other organizations in your area to see where you can immerse yourself.

Lastly, you can take a moment to acknowledge and give gratitude to the precious water you consume and use everyday.

story:
Short Summary

  • Hi! Thanks for taking a look at our campaign. My name is Anlezia Moné Venter. I created this story, developed and wrote the script, am currently busy in pre-production as Executive Producer, and later on, I will star as the protagonist in my first original screenplay: MATA HARI. I am currently in my last semester as a BFA Acting student at NYFA with full talent-based scholarship. 
  • In order to graduate, for part of my Thesis, I am to write, develop, produce and star in a short film. I was inspired by the story of Mata Hari. She was an undercover spy and exotic dancer in WW1, mainly in Paris. She was executed by firing squad in 1917, and her case was ordered to be sealed shut by the French Government for a 100 years. Next year, thus only, will the alluring mystery surrounding the infamous Mata Hari, be cleared up. Life is hard and unfair, and people like Mata Hari take the fall for government mistakes everyday. This is a tribute to her life. 

​

  • My film is a fictional interpretation of Mata Hari, a jazz singer and undercover spy, who was betrayed and turned into the government by the only man she wasn't with just to get information. She fell in love, and paid the ultimate price for it. 
  • It is important to me to tell this story to honor the memory of Mata Hari and what a celebratory, unapologetically beautiful woman she was. Up until her last moment, she chose dignity. She chose to express herself freely, instead of bowing her head and accepting defeat - despite the unjust things that happened to her.
  • On her last day, facing a firing squad of 12 soldiers, she refused to be tied to a pole. She wanted to look the soldiers who were about to shoot her, in their eyes. She removed her blindfold, blew a kiss to the soldiers and was shot dead. This is what my film will revolve around - her last moments and what lead up to that. 
  • With your generous support and donations, this tribute could be made a reality. With the funds raised, not only will I be able to finish this project I've been working on for months, and graduate with a BFA degree, I will also be able to have a film of high quality that I will be able to submit to numerous film festivals and share this beautiful tragedy, as well as gain exposure from the storytelling veterans in this industry - actors, directors, producers we all look up to. 
  • The exposure of this film will ultimately help me in the application for my O-1 Artists Visa, a visa that will allow me to work as an actress in the United States, which is a lifelong dream. 
  • When successful as a short film in the festival circuit, I also dream to develop this story into a feature film; Mata Hari's story is so rich and beautiful, I am extremely passionate about giving her life more than 5 minutes of tribute, (when we get there). 

But for now...

What We Need & What You Get

Films are really expensive to make, no matter the size. This is technically a no-budget film, however, below follows a breakdown of the funds we need to make this vision a reality. 

  • Meals & Craft Services: The very hardworking crew and cast need to refuel their energy!
  • Props: Our story is set in WW1, thus to make it look beautiful, we need a lot of 'period' props. 
  • Costumes: To truthfully convey the 'world' the story is set in, accurate costuming is essential. 
  • Set-Dressing: The set-dressing incorporates and completes the world wherein the story is set. In a period piece, it is essential for all the detail of the set time period to be represented as accurately as possible. 
  • Transportation & Travel: Firstly, We need to transport all the equipment and props from Cape Town to the town the locations are in. Furthermore, Principal Photography is scheduled for South Africa, because we found an absolutely amazing crew there, and production costs are lowered significantly, but first we need to get there. 
  • Equipment: To make the film look great, we need camera and lighting equipment. 
  • Hair & Make-Up: A lot of detail goes into making the cast look like they're from the 1910's. 
  • Film Festivals: Believe it or not, film festivals average about $40 - $50 per festival. Screening this film at festivals around the world to industry professionals, will make the months of hard work and all the funds worth it. 
  • Insurance: For the safety of everyone involved on set as well as the wonderful equipment, production insurance is required to make sure we don't have any unwanted surprises. 
  • Contingency: Despite months of meticulous planning, unforeseen things always come up. 
  • If we don't reach the minimum funds goal, we will put the raised funds firstly towards absolutely essential set-dressing and props. All raised funds will go toward covering costs of making this film. 
  • Fee - Indiegogo fee for raising the money. 

Risks & Challenges

There are numerous amounts of daily challenges involved in creating and producing a film, but everyone involved by making and funding it can be sure it will get made before this year is over. #'nboermaak'nplan.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you so much for donating to this campaign, we will be ever grateful to you. If it is not within your means, we absolutely completely understand. Please hep us gain support by sharing this project on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, or calling up an old friend! Any and all help is much appreciated. 

Meet the Team

EXECUTIVE PRODUCER, WRITER, ACTRESS: ANLEZIA MONÉ VENTER

Anlezia Moné Venter is an aspiring actress based in Los Angeles, California. She was born and raised in South Africa, and is returning to her roots to shoot her first original short film in Cape Town. Anlezia has always had a great passion for the arts and have participated in numerous theatre, musical theatre and short film productions, including an off-broadway performance while studying in New York. She is now finishing her BFA in Acting for Film at the New York Film Academy and dreams to work as an actress and producer both in the United States and South Africa upon completion of her degree. Anlezia has created this film, inspired by Mata Hari and is very thankful and beyond excited to collaborate with such a passionate group of artists.

DIRECTOR: ELLA VAN HEERDEN

Elmeri van Heerden is an actress, writer, director and acting coach and started her career in 2007 after completing a Master’s Degree in Theatre and Film studies from the University of Stellenbosch.  She completed her Post-grad Certificate in Education (Cum Laude) in 2015 and is currently in the process of applying for her Phd in performance arts.  She has written and directed numerous theatre productions and is still active in the local film industry, both acting and on the production side.  Elmeri has also had a successful career in radio and won numerous awards while working in the radio industry between 2011 – 2014.  She currently resides in Cape Town.

DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY: RUDI GREMELS

Rudolf Gremels is an aspiring Director of Photography and is currently completing a Bachelor of Arts in Film and Television in Cape Town, South Africa. To assist his formal education in gaining filmmaking knowledge, Rudolf has taken the initiative of entering important circles in the Cape Town film industry and has over the past three years assisted in the camera department on international commercials, as well as local feature films and televisions series. He has spent a significant amount of time behind the viewfinder himself; in addition to having shot over a dozen student projects, Rudolf has lensed a corporate video for a highly important charity organisation (The Amy Biehl Foundation). Rudolf’s active approach towards filmmaking has earned him a position in a highly regarded film crew agency in Cape Town; a professional entry into the industry awaits him after his graduation.

PRODUCER: MARLI VISSER

Marli Visser is currently a BA Film student at City Varsity, School of Media and Creative Arts in Cape Town, South Africa where she is majoring in Producing and Directing. She is an aspiring young filmmaker. Her goal is to become an accomplished producer in the film industry. She has a passion for turning ideas into a films that people enjoy to watch. The techniques and skills around creating a successful film, and the way that an idea can be turned into entertainment is what attracts her to the industry. Training to be a filmmaker, she has been involved in several projects respectively as producer, director and writer.  

PRODUCER: DYLAN VERMAAK

Dylan Vermaak is currently a BA film student at City Varsity, School of Media and Creative arts in Cape Town, South Africa where he is majoring in Directing and Producing. His aspiration in life is to be a storyteller. His goal is to become a successful working director in the film industry. Creativity is in his blood. He paints and he designs. Since he was a child he has been mesmerized by film and performing. To him, it’s a new world, a magical one filled with endless possibilities – one that he wants to inhabit. Each film is unique and fulfilling. Every creation is a story, a snapshot of life in some way that allows one to look through the window and experience someone else’s problems or issues and even triumphs in some way. He is interested in the power that film has to facilitate awareness of social issues and the power that lies within the medium to promote change in the world. To him, the visual medium- be it film or television, is an important and powerful tool in education and media and will play an ever increasing role in the future. He has been involved in several projects respectively as producer, director and writer.

VISUAL REFERENCES


 

* I DO NOT OWN THE COPYRIGHT TO ANY OF THESE PICTURES. THEY ARE FOR PRE-PRODUCTION REFERENCE PURPOSES ONLY.
